description:
This is one of those Chinese-Vietnamese places in Little Saigon that consistently serves up good quality dishes at really, really affordable prices.  As a food destination, SF has really become quite bifurcated between cheap ethnic places and expensive fine dining establishments. 

As much as I enjoy the experience at a Michelin-starred restaurant, sometimes I just want to eat some deep fried fish with some white rice and eat with my hands. This place probably serves the most inexpensive and still good quality deep fried fish (Tilapia for $9, Pompano for $10) in all of SF.  The service is OK but it can get quite loud. There's a lot of great ethnic places in the area but this restaurant holds its own.  Note that they accept cash only.
author: Andrew S.

description: This place has been open for over 25 years. It definitely has more options compared to back than. The food is nothing wow but acceptable. It has like a classic comfort kind of food mix chinese Vietnamese cuisine. I've always loved their pancake(rice cake) with eggs which I always ask for extra egg. A very close person of mine (rip) introduce it to me during my high school years and it has been and will always be our favorite. Service isn't perfect to others expectations but I've always had great service so I'm happy. This place you can say has a history with me growing up along with those who grew up in TL. I hope they stay open for a long long time.
author: Christy V.

description:
After my fiancé and I got some random pedicures in the Marina District, the nice old Vietnamese ladies said that Them Ky is the place to be to get Vietnamese food in SF. So, we made our way to the TL, putting our lives in danger, in the name of good food!

The concept of "the dirtier a place, the better tasting it is" applies here. Also, since it's cash only, you know they're hustling! That's just more justification why this place is authentically delicious.

We got the catfish in a stone pot, some sour soup, and the taro pancakes with egg. Everything was pretty tasty. I like how they have pictures of everything on the walls. Service is typical Vietnamese restaurant where they pretty much take your order, deliver the food, and you don't see anyone again.

Anyway, great place for some amazing Vietnamese food in the TL!
author: Marlon T.

description: Scary neighborhood but food are brilliant here.  Noodle soup are fantastic, we ate hot pot, it was fun and we had several different kinds of noodles instead of just one in typical bowl.  Great for lunch, don't know bout visit this area at night !
author: CAScuba Y.

description: Pho comes out hugh and hot.  Meat is a bit tough.  Tendons ate so tender.  Rice noodles is hugh but breaks up easily.  Ive tried many different items, never the same dish twice.  This place stays open late while every other one is closed.
author: Helen L.

description: Came here on a Friday for lunch. Nice service and solid food. I liked the pho broth here more than at Pho 2000. The rice for the Hai nan chicken is flavorful, but the chicken itself was pretty bland. Chicken salad was good.
author: Annie C.

description:
Despite a smaller restaurant, the lower rating and a low health department score, I liked Them Ky much better than Ha Nam Ninh (located across the street); as many of you have read. The people and workers are much friendlier and efficient. More importantly, they did not call me, "Sir". 

I was here for dinner. I had #84; Five-spiced chicken with shredded pork and an egg mixture over rice. For $9.00, the hefty portion was just the right amount and cooked to perfection. The grilled chicken is very moist and not too arid. 

I also ordered a colorful jelly drink with my meal. For $3.50, I get a concoction mixture of colorful jelly and beans in creamy sweet milk. This is not a bad treat or dessert (however you look at it). And the sweet milk is not overly sweetened!

The Tenderloin has many good Vietnamese restaurants. Them Ky is a good one.
author: Matt G.

description: I had the five item and rice, every bit of it was delicious and I had enough left over for a second meal. I was pleasantly surprised by the egg loaf with crab, super yum! My younger son had the prawns and spareribs in clay pot.  My elder had the beef chow mein. They were both happy with choices. Fair priced and I found the pictures helpful.
author: Cat H.

description:
Food = good.  But some items are misses.  

#1 Egg rolls = good. But needs more seasoning. $6.25.

#15 Radish pancake with eggs = boring, boring, and where is the turnip?! :(  Very disappointing. $7.95.

#48 Charbroiled chicken with rice vermicelli and vegetables = great chicken, juicy and full of flavor. Plenty of food for one.  Definitely worth a try. $8.45 x2.

#120 Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk = strong and good. $3.25.

#137 Three color drink = perfect. Not too sweet. $3.25.

Service = friendly.  

Prices = reasonable. $40.89 for all of the above. 

Seating = plentiful. Mostly 4-tops.  

Parking = street.
author: Fannie S.

description:
closest to TK Noodle you're gonna get in SF.

Great standard combo rice stick noodle soup.

Good fried egg rolls.
author: Megan L.

description:
The food is serious here.  Their clear noodles combo is good.  I like the option of having it "dry' style so that I can add as much liquid as I feel like.  one time it was super good but sometimes it's hit or miss.  The sauce was amazing but they lose one star b/c I like consistency and it's not exactly consistent here.  The Cha Gio/spring roll wrapped in a soft wrap is good, but they used to have another type here that was better imo. 

They have a Chinese pancake here; I think Shanghainese style & it's very good with the sauce. I highly recommend it, but sometimes it's very burnt.  So i'd check it first personally, especially if you plan to take it to go.  

It scares me that their cleanliness or food safety is 57/100 what really??!! It's posted on yelp but I'm not sure how accurate, anyone saw a sign there?  And negative that they DO NOT accept credit cards.  

However, yes of all the negativity I would still come here due to the fact that I notice they give free food to some neighborhood hobos that peep in to ask for just rice or noodles and I think the bum is a regular?  That type of act of kindness makes me feel like I'm doing something good by just eating here.  This is part of the business ethics so personally I think it deserves to be in the review.  Sharing is caring.  :]  When you're having a warm meal indoors, then you look at the poor dude hanging out in the cold wearing a garbage bag...it's like ouch.  right?  But I felt ok today, b/c the hobo got food at the same place too lol.  I saw him carry out like 3 boxes so I'm glad he's fed too.  Props for that.  I hope other restaurants would do the same for neighborhood bums.  

It doesn't cost too much to spare a meal here and there.  I would do it too
author: Juila L.

description: The food is good lots to choose from but that also could be a bad thing or good thing depending on the person when you have a small menu and you're good at one particular item that would sell more so all the other items it's good for people who can't decide but also you have to understand that those items might not sell as much and not as fresh. But hey that's just my opinion I really like their Imperial roll with BBQ pork vermicelli the price is pretty good as far as portion wise. Only complaint I have is the place is super dirty I don't think I could sit there and go through a meal without looking around and underneath the table but then again that's just me.
author: Michele T.

description:
Great variety of noodle soup selections as well as plate entrees!

If you are confused about what to order, they have food pictures up on the wall!  It helps with the vision!

You can expect meals to be in the 10 dollar range!

I love their fried egg rolls here!  It is the bomb with the sauce that they provide with the dish!  They have good pho noodles and broth!  It is comfort food - especially on a cold, foggy SF day!

Don't expect top notch dining at this spot, but sufficient chairs and tables!  

Cash only - unavailable swiping of cards at this time!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Large menu and reasonable prices. They have items such as pan fried turnip cake w/ egg and Bun Nuoc Leo that can't be found at a lot of restaurants. I see a lot of people get he broiled catfish but have t tried that myself. Maybe next time.
author: Julie L.

description:
I adore this place! I've been to the more famous restaurant next door (Hai Ky Mi Gia) and I like Them Ky better. This place is legit with some pretty authentic dishes (a lot of offal to go around). I came here for lunch with a coworker and we shared the taro cake appetizer place and Ariel ordered the combination beef parts pho (don't know how else to call it, but it has beef balls, stewed beef, tendon and sirloin) and I had the beef stew pho. 

The taro cake is en pointe. I love taro and the egg batter isn't oily at all. The little bits of peanuts and pickled daikon added crunch and a bit of salty/sweet to the dish. The fresh scallions added a freshness element. I think it's a must order.

The stewed beef pho is also great. The meat and tendons are cooked down and the stew is so flavorful. My only complaint is that the rice noodles are slightly overcooked and could be a bit more chewy, but that's a minor complaint.

Overall, I highly recommend this place. It has a lot of dishes that you can't get at Americanize Vietnamese places. The price is cheap and the wait is short. I would like to go back and try the curried lamb stew pho. Can't wait!
author: Alice W.

description: This is my go to place to get my fix of the vietnamese "broken rice" combination rice plate. No. 88 on the menu.
author: Ferdy S.

description:
Came here for a vietnamese banh mi sandwich. It was made to order and the bread was fresh - crispy and flakey, just the way I like it. The meat had a great flavor. The one downside is that they don't have pate. 

Here's a cool article from Tasting Table about Them Ky Restaurant:
http://www.tastingtable.com/entry_detail/sf/12507/Go_beyond_the_deli_for_lunch.htm#ixzz2Ty8pb4nN

If I lived in the city, I'd frequent this little hole in the wall...
author: Denise H.

description:
This is my 2nd time I've been to this place.  First time I went with friends and they ordered some fried dishes which I thought was ok.

This time,  I tried this place because Turtle Tower and Pho 2000 were both closed.  I figured, how bad can a pho place in Little Saigon be...?

Was I wrong!  The bowl of noodles arrived and I dug in as I was starving.  First thing I noticed was the soup had a strange sweet taste.  Smelling it further, it smelled somewhat fishy.  Did they add fish sauce to the beef pho?   The meat was chewy which is not a good sign.  The noodles themselves were all clumped together and not broken apart...  

I am not a person that likes to waste food but I could not eat this bowl of noodles!  I've never had anything like this before.  When I paid for my meal, the lady asked me if I wanted a to-go box for my noodles since it looked like I haven't touched it.  I told her I didn't want it.  She looked at me and said, "I'm sorry".  That made me feel very bad but I didn't have a response for her.  I paid for my meal and walked out... down the street to get another bowl of noodles.
author: Philip L.

description:
Cheap (~$8 for a big bowl!), but not that good. Beef Pho broth lacked rich flavor, but included lots of meat and toppings. There was enough noodles to fill 2 people.

Opens early. Would return only for their iced vietnamese coffee.
author: Jess C.

description:
With a few of my favorite pho joints relatively close to me (PPQ!), it's not often I head down to the TL just to get a bowl of pho.  If and when I would though, Them Ky was usually my go-to choice - solid food, reasonable prices, and plenty of seating.  So while it's great that two of the three are still true, the most important one (the food) is nothing like I remember.

As my friend and I flipped through the menu, it looked as though a handful of items had been added since my last trip.  Since it's been a couple of years though, I can't say for sure.  Regardless, I stuck with two of my usual orders at Them Ky - Beef Pho with Rare Steak and Well Done Flank (Tai Chin?) and a BBQ Pork Banh Mi to take back home.  

While the noodles and rare steak in the pho were fine (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/them-ky-san-francisco?select=lB5No76lFJslYC81aTd5eg#0JF_dZVeHjDpoqdoPH41jQ), I thought the flank was a bit tough and that the broth was a little funky.  I can't really describe it, but rather than a rich and savory flavor, it tasted somewhat fragrant to me.  Perhaps it was just one bad mix of seasonings (or the spoon they gave me that smelled like bleach), but it didn't seem that way before.  Although it was edible, I admit I added a decent amount of sriracha and plum sauce to cover it up.

As for the banh mi (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/them-ky-san-francisco?select=lB5No76lFJslYC81aTd5eg#YupN36mDq86flORUBkhp8w), it's still pretty decent, but I remember liking it more before than I do now.  I don't know if it's my preferences that have changed or the rolls that they use, but I wish the bread was a little lighter.  Again, that's just what I prefer though; otherwise, it's still a pretty good sandwich and the meat still nicely seasoned and flavorful.

I'm sure at some point I'll be back in the TL again for another bowl of pho, but I'll probably look to try a couple of other places before I come back to Them Ky again.

CASH ONLY.
author: Mike L.

description:
This place is kinda in the cuts but it's worth it for their Vietnamese food! They have the most variety and options on their menu that I've ever seen at a Vietnamese place. In some places, this might mean everything is mediocre, but it works at Them Ky! 

The beef pho is really good. They have some of the best noodles and broth. The noodles are nice and chewy and the broth is very flavorful. 

Another of my favorites is the eggplant fish rice plate with Vietnamese rice. 

Their service is quick and friendly, and prices are cheap :)
author: Sze-Wing L.

description:
OK, I have to admit I was kinda nervous eating here. I call it the Tu Lan Too Little Too Late Syndrome. It's that creeping feeling you have when you step into a family-run restaurant that looks rather run down with the slightly faded photos of their specialty dishes on the wall, but you feel like you committed yourself because you're the only one in the place about to eat their food. Your conscience overrides any health concerns you are about to face by sitting down and ordering something off their menu.

After all, what's so bad about a stomach pump when you're helping a business survive for another day? Them Ky is not quite that bleak. There appears to be a stream of regulars who come here and trade bon mots with the ladies who run the joint. The food didn't appear to be hazardous either since here I am writing this review in an upright position several days later. My motivation for coming here was that they serve Steamed Chicken. Yes, many people chafe at the concept, but I happen to like it if it's prepared right.

They prepare it decently, but the portion is quite skimpy with a whole lot of rice to offset the plate (see photo). No chopped ginger and garlic to spread on it either, just a nondescript sauce for dipping. I guess I shouldn't have expected too much for $6.45. I had better luck with the $4.75 Shrimp-Pork Rolls, which turned out to be a pair of jumbo-size spring rolls filled with a lot of lettuce and cellophane noodles. At least they served the right sauce for that - a thick peanut one with chopped peanuts on top, an ample amount for dipping (see photo). Will I return? Maybe but I may need to take some meds for my syndrome beforehand.

FOOD - 3 stars...decent enough with a robust spring roll that pushes this rating up a bit
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...well, if I had stock in Formica...
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...a bit surly but not too surprising
TOTAL - 3 stars...Tu Lan revisited?...well, er, umm....
author: Ed U.

description:
This one might be my new favorite.

*Tasty broths and sauces
*Big portions
*Many, many choices
*Photos of each dish on the walls
*Great service
*Super reasonable prices

So I've had a lot of dishes here but I highly recommend the oxtail stew and the lamb curry.  The portions are huge and everything is so flavorful...Also last time we went, my GF  wanted something healthy, she proceeded to describe to the waitress the salad she had in mind that did not exist on the menu and the waitress said it wasn't a problem (despite the hundreds of options on the menu...) and came back with a beautifully executed shrimp salad full of flavor created by, among other things: ginger, mint and garlic and delicious fish sauce.  Oh and the Banh Mi sandwiches are some of the best in town.

Goodness
author: Monkey B.

description:
SOBBING ON ELLIS STREET That was me a few years back leaping up kicking back my chair and running out crying because at my left elbow on the saucer of bean sprouts for my steaming bowl of pho was a lively gigantic bug the nasty sort that spooks me and makes cry.  My friend paid and tried to kill the beast bug but it slipped out of his napkin.

Before that ate there scores of times my gang loved the food and the staff! Now I see they have a seriously bad health score obviously they need to be fumigated.
author: SF T.

description:
The food was okay, it's definitely authentic, complete with the cook yelling at the waiter loudly during lunch time.  Got to love these family owned restaurants.

Their menu is very extensive with a combination of Viet and Chinese food it seems.

I'd go back again....just not often.
author: Edward M.

description: Huge portions for vermicelli and rice plates to go. Had the chicken pho here and very good on the broth.
author: Ju D.

description:
Hungry and looking for tasty, inexpensive food? Them Ky is the spot.

They offer a large selection of delicious-looking dishes displayed on the walls, as well as in their menu. It was tough to choose which one I wanted to order considering their generous portions.

I settled on my ol' favorite - the cold vermicelli noodle salad with spring rolls, veg and fish sauce as dressing. At this establishment, it was the #41 and delicious. At $6.95 it was friendly on the wallet ~ I could've saved 1/2 for another meal.

Atmosphere is hole in the wall, a bit cluttered-homey, service friendly and they have a TV to keep you entertained while you nosh.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Haven't dined here in a while, but my mom and I recently ordered Ca Nuong to-go here.

Excited that they now serve one of my favorite Vietnamese specialties: Ca Nuong (Vietnamese Roasted Catfish)! It takes 45 mins. for the fish to cook (call in early to order) and is about $33.

This Ca Nuong dish comes with rice paper, veggies, and two dipping sauces to make spring rolls. So instead of making your spring rolls with shrimp/pork, you would be making it w/ the roasted fish.

Must order the banh hoi (Vietnamese steamed rice vermicelli noodles) to add into the spring rolls also. Banh hoi is sold separately - $3 per order.
author: B. R.

description:
**HIDDEN GEM ALERT** 
Wow the people here are so friendly and the food is so delicious!! My boyfriend and I were in the area seeking some cheap dinner so we dropped in and they sat us down with some tea. We decided to just get banh mi's to go but the server insisted that we sat and drank some tea while we waited anyways. 

It took awhile for the banh mi's to come but boy were they worth the wait!!! I wasn't expecting much because the banh mi's seemed like an afterthought on the menu, after all it was the cheapest item on the menu at $4. I got the bbq chicken banh mi and my partner got the bbq pork banh mi and it was SO DELICIOUS!!! The bread was warm and crispy but not hard and was easy to bite into. I wasn't expecting much out of the chicken but the meat was SO TENDER!! It had a wonderful balance in flavor! 

I am so excited to go back and try some more of their food because it looks freaking amazing. 
It doesn't look too fancy on the inside but I believe the value of a food establishment relies on the quality of their food and customer service. And they've won my 5 stars for both!
author: Nancy W.

description:
One of my favs when i am flush and slumming in that part of town. 
The House Special Salad is a vegetarians delight (just give the shrimp chips to your non-vegetarian dining partner). The Pho is enough for two normal people, but perfect for a growing boy like myself. The spring rolls are great, and I love the Clay Pot Shrimp and Spareribs, which may or may not be authentic Vietnamese, but who's asking?
author: Joseph T.

description: They actually don't open till 10am now. Cash only. Food is good, not the most friendliest of staff and the wait time for food varies.
author: Judy L.

description:
Was planning to visit the bigger restaurant next door but decided to give this place a try, good call.

First visit, we had:
bun bo hue - not bad but definitely not spicy enough
tomato beef stew noodle - the beef stew was tender and flavorful

Second visit, we had:
turnip cake - portion is smaller than I expected but it was good.  pan fried with eggs and some preserved turnip bits, tasty dipping sauce

curry lamb rice noodle - very good curry but not a lot of lamb, the lamb pieces are also mostly bone.  the rice noodle soaked up the sauce/soup very fast.

pho - it was good, only wish it was piping hot.

We will definitely return.  Cash only.
author: Gloria H.

description:
We order two different things: 

1) Shrimp and pork egg noodle soup: this was okay except the broth was a little bland...i wasn't crazy about it
2) Shredded pork and egg rice: this was better, except the egg was a bit lumpy.

my favorite part was just the convenience; the place was easy to find and the service was pretty fast. however, not the best vietnamese place in the TL or sf
author: Thach N.

description:
Large portions of food! They have a big variety of dishes to choose from. It can get a bit overwhelming but my entire party enjoyed everything we ordered :) 

This restaurant has been around for 22 years and the owners are very very nice! I highly recommend anyone to try this place if they're in the area. I'll definitely be back again!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
MmMmmM yeah... Hai Ky was closed (dammit..)
It's a loud  dirty hole in the wall restaurant. They give you a plentiful amount of food...But the taste in my noodles were just.. oily. It tasted like grease and nothing but grease. I added white pepper, hot sauce, and soy sauce but I still got nothing out of my ho fun noodles. 
I mean I guess it's alright but their service is out of wack. I don't expect much from these dingy hole in the wall joints but my friend got her food 10 minutes before me.. And order after order after order of other peoples' food came out before me as well. It was torture with a big letdown. Boner kill much?
The vermicelli bowl is huge though. They give you a ton of noodle and the meat is grilled up nicely.

P.S. This is the only spot I know of in the TL that has porridge.
author: Susy C.

description:
As someone who grew up eating pho and around people who know how to make the best of them, I must say that this place does it right from the first slurp to finish. I've been to several places in San Francisco and West LA where the soup was either sweet or diluted, beef was already well done, side dish of sprouts were unclean and not fresh, or somehow certain key ingredients were skipped over. You won't find any of those weak links here in your piping hot bowl of pho.

I come here a lot. This is not a place to bring a date or to find decent services, but I'm always assured to have a pure a hole in the wall comfort food experience. In my previous visits the server was always absent minded and won't pay attention unless I was with a big party. But in exchange I find them offering one of the most dynamic menus when compare to similar types of pho restaurants. 

More importantly their food lives up to its billing as I find their pho tai gan ($6) and dac biet xe lua ($6.45) top notch and hard to beat. I have had their pho with rare beef and tendon several times. The broth is always rich and flavorful anchored by a nice depth of bone marrow taste. The soup is served very hot so that their still firm noodles and rare beef and buttery tendon can be appropriately steeped with fresh servings of jalapenos, sprouts and basil leafs. It's hard to imagine a more complete bowl of pho. Whereas some places have their soup base inconsistent from opening to closing, my experiences here have been as good as it gets regardless whether I was here for brunch, late lunch or last night's dinner.  We are talkin' about smackin' pho power with tons of street cred straight out of the Tenderloin.

If you are ever tempted to get an appetizer, try their egg roll with shredded pork rolls with lettuce ($5.50). It comes with two huge spring rolls tightly wrapped with layers of lettuce, shredded pork and crunchy delicious Vietnamese egg rolls at the core. This was one of the most unique and delicious rolls I've tried. In my previous visits I also enjoyed their com ga hap Hai Nam ($6.45) and com bi cha suon nuong ($6.45). I thought the Hai Nan chicken was really great with their rice nicely seasoned, and although the pork chop was decent, I've also had it better at Pho 99 in Daily City. The only item that I would not recommend is their oxtail over rice which I thought was too boney and the stew itself was dry and not very flavorful. 

The culmination of these experiences leading up to last night made this my go-to place for pho. I must try their taro pancake with eggs ($6) for my next visit, among a whole slew of other interesting dishes that I have mentally bookmarked. Aside from the service, my only complaints are their super hot tea that makes the cup hard to hold and their chopsticks are not the cleanest. Adding my list of positive experiences to good prices, it's been 4.5 stars every time I'm here.

B.B, this place has a fried chicken leg dish with your name on it. I hope that you check it out.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I had the bun bo hue here (what else?), and it isn't very spicy, which I like.  It comes with the pale pork ham/sausage/roll (you know what I'm talking about), pork blood, beef and beef tendon.  I told them to skip the pork hock... the only part I never eat.  It's accompanied by raw bean sprouts, cabbage, mint leaves, and a lemon.  No basil... darn.  I don't care for mint leaves much.

Overall it tasted... okay.  The noodles weren't bad, the meat was a bit tough, and the soup was pretty well-seasoned.  The only problem was the smell of the soup... I couldn't detect it, it smelled and tasted a bit like... there was cabbage or kale in there. Or something. This is when I drank the soup straight, without noodles, veggies or anything diluting it.  It was kind of unpleasant.

I don't think I'll come back, since I prefer Sao Bien across the street.  The staff were really friendly, and at $7.54 including tax, it's a slightly cheaper than the other TL BBHs.
author: Erika C.

description:
This is my first time here with a party of 5 and the experience I had was very disappointing.
Firstly, horrible service, no one cared to take our orders, make no mistake, the place was not busy (I was there around 7pm). I had to scout for an available waiter. 
Secondly, one of my friends got the wrong item. Thirdly, the most important factor of a 5 star restaurant, the quality of the food---which was below average. 
Our group ordered Hainan Chicken Rice, Chinese and Taro Pancakes, none of the items were delicious at all. The chicken was bland, they gave me some kind of sour sauce that I was supposed to dip the chicken in to compensate for the lack of flavor. The Chicken dish was inauthentic and not good. I have had Hainan Chicken Rice before and I can guarantee that is not how the dish should be served with. 
The pancakes could only fool people to think they are good only if those people are STARVING and HAVE NEVER HAD Chinese/Taro pancakes before.

Lastly, poor food safety score (I just found out when I log onto Yelp to rate this place). I sincerely hope the manager reads the criticisms and make honest efforts to improve the place.
author: Alex H.

description:
After a poor initial experience at Bodega Bistro, my friends and I got up, quickly checked Yelp for the nearest still-open pho restaurant (they were all closing as it was around 6:30 pm on Sunday), found this place just around the corner, and booked it over here.

I ordered tai nam gau gan sach pho (pretty much pho with everything except meatballs). My friends ordered the bun bo hue and pho ga (chicken pho).

Verdicts:
Beef pho: good; I'd come here again for this...if Pho 2000 or Kevin's Noodle House wasn't open at the time, this is a great backup

Bun bo hue: Vietnamese friends in the group loved it! They said it was better than the pho, which had soggy noodles. I don't like bun bo hue in general so I'm good with the pho.

Chicken pho: mediocre; I mean, how can you compete with Turtle Tower right around the corner?

What a satisfying, full meal for $6.95. Bodega Bistro, I don't even think I'm going to try you now.
author: Esther Y.

description:
Fire roasted.

You can get tomatoes in a can: http://www.hunts.com/products/tomatoes/diced-tomatoes

Or you can get tomatoes as part of a steaming hot house special soup with a generous assortment of seafood, sprouts and noodles in a tomato broth.

Couldn't believe how good it was. Couldn't believe it was just $8.

Perhaps their signature dish unless you try the $4 roasted chicken bánh mì on a just the right amount of softness roll. Flavor kept coming. So did the tasty prices.

Seemed like the lady helping me took more time to answer my questions than it took for the food to be prepared. Took even less time to eat it.

Extra large photos of the various menu items adorn the walls along with strands of lights. No reason why not. They should be proud of their offerings.

This place is on fire.
author: Jason B.

description:
I began my love affair with pho here but have long ago switched to Golden Flower/Evergreen as my go to spots when I'm in town. Found myself in the TL and decided to give Them Ky a return visit which reminded me both why I liked it and why I went away.

On the plus side the serving size of both the pho (wherever I go, I always get the beef combination with tripe and tendon but no meat balls) and herbal accompaniments was generous and the service lightning-fast. But the broth is just a little weaker and the noodles starchier compared to the twins mentioned above.

This is still the best pho in the block, which is saying something because of the choices available. If you are here (and find a parking spot) and the pho bug bites you, do not hesitate to walk right in.
author: Otis M.

description: Definitely not a place to take your family or date. Up next to the counter was ant/roach spray, behind the counter was a mess and the food was just okay. Very traditional food, without a lot of flavor. I had to ask for sugar, salt, pepper and other spices to make my broccoli beef tolerable. My friend had a sweet/sour chicken that tasted mostly like vinegar and smelled like bleach. (Yes bleach) Customer service was nice when we got the lady who spoke english. Most of the employee's do not, which is not bad but annoying when you need something and you have to go through a chain of command just to ask for some sugar, silverware, extra napkins etc.
author: Savannah Veronica J.

description: This little hole in the wall is great. Very fast service and sometimes friendly staff, lol. I usually order their whole bbq catfish and make my own spring rolls with some friends. It's a great interactive meal that is reasonable and delicious. I recommend it a lot.
author: Miko L.

description:
Okay so let's me see. My friends and I have tried Com Ga Hai Nam (Chicken Rice), Banh Hoi, Bot Chien (Pancake with Egg??!), and Seafood Noodle Soup. 

As a VBV (Vietnamese Born Vietnamese) I would say the Chicken Rice is pretty delicious and authentic. I'd definitely recommend that to my friend - which I did!

Banh Hoi is an okay since it's not so authentic (How did they think of eating them with Meatball??? Don't they have Grilled Pig here in the US??? - which actually yes they do.) 

About Bot Chien, I don't know how about yours but mine was a total blackness - like the food was burned to death. Also, it should be eat with fish sauce, not soy sauce but it's okay, not too bad. Yeah I'm that easy. 

Seafood Noodle Soup was a bit tasteless but after adding some chili sauce, I was good to go. For some reason though, they use Chinese noodle in stead of the Bun in Bun Bo Hue (The big white noodle) so I told her I prefer the Bun and she said, "Yeah it goes with the Bun!" (No it's not, I saw your menu's picture on the wall!)

Anyway, the lady was really nice to us. The food is cheap but pretty delicious.  I'd definitely go here again to try other food!

PS: Don't drink Egg Soda (Or whatever you know what I mean) Just my own little opinion but DON'T DRINK IT.
author: Tran N.

description:
I was pretty disappointed here. The inside is relatively small, with limited seating, and it can be hard to get a spot during the lunch rush. With so many people here though, I expected the food to be better.

For my appetizer I ordered the cha gio (fried pork roll), which was disappointing. It was tasted over-fried and too oily. Wrapping it in lettuce, vegetables and vermicelli noodles and dipping it in the fish sauce makes it better; but good cha gio shouldn't require that and should be delicious by itself.

For my main, I had mi xao don hai san (seafood crispy chow mein), which was also disappointing. The seafood did not taste fresh, and the dish was overall pretty bland-tasting. Some of the noodles were also fused together in this annoying fried mass that just wasn't enjoyable to eat. The dish wasn't bad per se, but I felt more like I was putting nutrients in my mouth to feed myself than enjoying a good meal.

I'll give this place another try, because I've heard good things about it and I swear I've had some other good dishes here before, but until then 2 stars.
author: Phong Q.

description:
A lot of locals come here since since I've been there twice on both visits to SF and my friends seem to love this place.

Special spring rolls are so good that I really didn't need to order anything else, but did order Bun Bo Hue which was huge but didn't pack much flavor. Meat tasted old so I didn't really enjoy it. 

Beef Stew and Hainam chicken (you can request all white meat) were delicious. Service was great and they spoke English. Definitely go back to try other things
author: Robin S.

description:
Prices are very cheap (check out the Vietnamese sandwiches), and the food is no frills but absolutely great considering what they charge. This place is more Chinese than Vietnamese but I guess they're trying to blend in with all the Pho places nearby. Staff is very friendly.

My absolute favorite is the Ginger chicken, it makes me miss Hong Kong. The ginger sauce coming with it is a close contender to Lers Ros' chili sauce. :-)

This is not a place to go for a great dinner or anything. Rather when you are looking for good food for a small budget.
author: Tin Yan C.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE ! This is where I go whenever i'm craving to go out to eat Vietnamese food . 

They're really friendly nd they don't even expect a tip; you pay at tha front... well, that's what i usually do. I usually get this seafood combination chow mein with crunchy noodles, i order it in Vietnamese so i don't really know what tha engrish name for it is... I've tried their pho as well which was delightful nd BIG. it was enough to share with a buddy :D

This is a local place nd isn't VERY popular but it's awesome.. That's why i love this place so much. Their food is pretty cheap too but tastes great.
author: Michael N.

description:
We wanted to go to Ha Nam Nimh  for dinner on Friday evening but as observed by everyone lately, that place opens whenever it feels like it. 
So we were stuck with few Vietnamese options. We wandered over to Ha Nam Nimh hoping for good cheap eats. 
Well, it was pretty cheap but it was Not very tasty

Egg Rolls (Imperial rolls)- pretty good; but completely fell apart everytime i picked it up with chopsticks and tried to dip it in the fish sauce. Messy
Bun Bo Hue- terrible noodles; i like al dente but i think this was waaaay undercooked. Soup was ok. Meat in the dish was not really edible; very tough, compeletly overcooked.  I ended up just drinking the soup and eating the noodles

I'd completely skip this place
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
My boyfriend, cousin and I were craving some warm noodle soup on a cold rainy night.  Looked up some yelp reviews and stumbled upon this restaurant, 4 stars that is still opened. 

Walked in and saw Chinese words, with pictures of their dishes all over the walls.  Knew we walked into a good place already!  We were determined to order what we came here for - beef noodle soup! 

The orders came out really fast and from the look of the dark broth, I already knew it was going to be tasty!  Nonetheless, it did not disappoint!  The taste is so flavorful and taste so different! 

I ate mine so fast and it's literally a treasure find for me.  I'm determined to come back and try their meat dishes soon!
author: Nancy S.

description:
Hands down the WORST bowl of pho I've ever had.  

The waitress brought me the wrong order and then refused to acknowledge that it was incorrect even thought it clearly was.  My bowl was supposed to have rare steak, brisket and flank.  The bowl that she brought me had meat balls, tendon and tripe.  When I showed her the meatballs, she insisted that the #19 had meatballs.  I looked at the menu again and the #19 did not.  I showed her what was clearly tendon and tripe and she insisted that it was brisket.

Not only was the order wrong, but the soup just sucked.  The broth was murky and looked like dirty dishwater and had a weird overly sweet flavor.  There were so many noodles in the bowl that they absorbed all of the broth.  

Overall, just a horrendous experience and I certainly will never go back.
author: Brandon H.

description:
My brother wanted to take me to go somewhere new for pho and took me here. Now, my dad has been taken me here before I was a big yelper so it's a must to yelp this place!

Not the nicest restaurant, kind of a small hole in the wall but food here are delish! I ordered a number 29, steak and beef ball pho (yes! simple and my favorite!) It's so good! Really big portion! I usually could finish mines but... not this one. You know what makes pho...pho? The soup! The soup makes pho taste really good and this pho was GOOD!

Definitely recommend! Decent price, and big portion!
author: Lianne D.

description:
Hmmm maybe 3.5 stars.

I ordered the Bun Bo Hue, which wasn't bad.. I sense a tad of MSG though. My sister and mom ordered Pho, but for some reason they didn't like it very much. They mentioned it had a sour taste to the stock.

Granny ordered the Shrimp Cake and BBQ Pork rice platter which she liked a lot. 

The service wasn't bad.. But it wasn't good either. 

It wasn't too busy on a Tuesday afternoon. The food took a reasonable amount of time to come out, but the ladies kept bringing us plates that was supposed to for the other table. Maybe they need to be a bit more organized with that because it got annoying.
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
Their #43 will have to do (beef over rice w/ imperial roll) until my favorite Tu-Lan re-opens.
Very speedy service, but cash only and no ATM inside
author: Andrew Z.

description:
Finally found a soup I like here, the combo clear noodle soup. Shrimp, porkcake, ground pork, chicken, and squid over chewy clear noodles, with some kind of fermented paste and soup on the side.

What I realized in the process of finding this soup, is that this place definitely does not short you on the protein. Good bang for your buck here.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I came here on saturday looking forward to eating their pho as one of my friend's highly recommends this place... and unfortunately, this place is NG (no good)

I ordered the rare beef with tripe pho.

Reasons why i dont like my pho:
- broth eh was okay, was lacking umami
- beef and tripe - just average, nothing tho sing about
- noodles... YUCK... it had this chlorine smell to it... at first i thought i was the plasticware.  i smelled my chopstick... smelled my spoon, but the it was a strong chlorine smell... then i ate the noodles again... and that smell of chlorine just over whelms your entire mouth... gross.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Oh me oh my.... I'm going to have to downgrade Them Ky based on the steamed chicken over ginger and garlic rice dish. After a lackluster meal at Them Ky, I specifically returned to try this dish. I'm a HUGE fan of Hainanese chicken. Not such a huge fan of Them Ky's version. Here's what lacking:

-Juiciness: the chicken was overcooked, kinda chewy, and substantially lacking in edible meat to eat. I could barely get any meat off the bones. I filled up on the garlic rice.
-Flavor: It tasted like boiled chicken. There was no ginger essence to it at all. 
-Scallions & ginger: The only vegetables included were a side of Vietnamese pickled radishes and carrots. 

I had to force myself to finish this dish. Guess I'll have to keep going to Hunan Homes in Chinatown for my Hainanese chicken fix.
author: Monelle A.

description:
- The pho broth was bad, really bad
- Noodles in pho had weird taste
- Imperial Rolls were spoiled. Like, actually spoiled and sour tasting
- Service was almost non-existent 

Very sad, unsatisfying meal...
author: Jen D.

description:
I love pho!! Them Ky satisfied my tummy with a hot and HUGE bowl (I shared with my sister) of soupy noodles...not complaining here!

pho ga ($6.45) - There was real Chinese style chicken in the soup which was a plus. Definitely didn't lack in the noodle department...the soup was a tad salty but still very flavorful. I loved the spicy chili sauce (the real stuff...not like sriracha) they had at the table too that added some kick to the meal. Close to perfect and you get a lot for your money! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lw38MxB5AReAzXQVRrOfXg?select=GezQlM2zdWTKt6QvV1SRJw)

imperial rolls ($5) - These were fresh, hot, and crispy (2 rolls with 4 pieces each). As usual, it came with vermicelli, pickled carrots/turnip, cucumber, and lettuce on the side. The fish sauce made everything taste awesome too. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lw38MxB5AReAzXQVRrOfXg?select=H9wsC-67R1OWsl-88crJhg)

The service wasn't the greatest but I like how the tea came in a pot so that we didn't have to wait for refills. At least our food came out quick style! We devoured every bit of food because it was so delicious!! Will be back!
author: Karen Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite Chinese Vietnamese places in Little Saigon!  And apparently it's somewhat of a secret since it's slightly off of Larkin.

What to Order Here:
Bun Bo Hue ($6.95)
Lamb Curry with French Bread or Rice ($8.95)
Pho ($6.95)

What Not to Order:
Glazed Catfish ($8.95) mainly because of the small portion size

A note of warning.  My friend had to drag me away from the restaurant last time because I was so engrossed in this Chinese dating show that they were blasting from the TV monitors.  This could happen to you.
author: Fei L.

description:
Since I've been twice now, I'd like to offer a few opinions about Them Ky.  So far so good, it was a total stumble.  I can't say the decor drew me in - it is very spartan, with the main decoration being color photos of the food on the wall, but the pictures are large and they do actually do the food some justice.

I can vouch for a solid Pho Ga.  I tend to go against the grain and eat my Pho without noodles, which in some countries I believe is a felony!  But I like my chicken soup with extra Gai Lan and the folks at Them Ky are OK with that.  I at least don't get the stink eye for being a non-noodle eater.

I recently ordered a beef Banh Mi with my soup at lunch time.  This sandwich was a steal and a half at 3 bucks.  I found they serve grilled marinated beef sannies here- which was a delight, albeit a bit rare to find.  Banh Mi usually seem to be of the pork, chicken or tofu variety.  The beef was tasty, some marinated top round probably, but hey it had flavor and was not too chewy.  Best part is that there was some real grill flavor here, which is hard to find these days. I'm no native Vietnamese but I'd bet my bottom dong( oh wait, trying to be funny saying "bet my bottom dollar" turns out its a weird pun on the Vietnamese currency), that real Vietnamese cuisine prides itself on mastery of imparting great grill flavor to its meats.

I mean 3 bucks?!?  Fresh and tasty! The  All veggies super fresh, and a little mayo to boot. 

Note:  Been coming back here a lot for the aforementioned Banh Mi.  Solid every time.  Best eaten right there- fresh with the meat still warm.  Not much for ambiance there, but if you can get over that hump and focus on the food- its worth it.  

By the way, they do a great job with to go food orders.  I get the Pho Ga here often, they serve it with steamed skinless breast meat, and tons of herbs.  Their broth is basic, but flavorful, and you can dress it up when you get home. 

Summary - dingy atmosphere, but the food is consistent, a good value, and if you don't like the ambiance, order your food for pick up.  Cash only, by the way.
author: Kevin M.

description:
The yummy place next door was closed so we decided to give Them Ky a shot. Big mistake.

The fish soup tasted like perfume. The fried chicken was overcooked and dry. The spring roll wrappers were hard like they were not soaked long enough in water prior to wrapping.

The only redeeming item was my three color jelly drink.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
You know since Golden House on Golden Gate Avenue closed, I've been searching for a place that serves a good bowl of bun, spring roll, and bbq'd meat.  I will say that Them Ky does serve a good bowl of that, maybe not quite as good as Golden House did or Pink Flamingo, for those of you that remember that place.  That being said, I would definitely go back if I needed a bun fix.  

My friend got the Pho and didn't like it.  Said the broth was kinda weird.
author: Ray R.

description:
Just okay food, not bad, but not outstanding either. I ordered the cha gio and the steamed chicken over garlic rice. The cha gio (imperial rolls) was average, similar to My Canh, but larger. In my opinion, the best cha gio in this area can be found at Pagolac or Bodega Bistro, followed by Mangosteen, and Turtle Tower. The steamed chicken was tender and flavor was okay, but I've had much better versions, and the garlic rice was garlicky good.

- Decent space, fairly clean, lots of space to sit, it's never full.
- Cheap prices, under $7.
- Extensive menu, and pictures of common dishes on the walls.
- Generous portions. The plates are literally overflowing with food.
- VERY friendly service, specially the short handicapped woman, who greets customers with a cheerful "Hi". But she only knows a few words in English so do not expect to be able to have a conversation. The rest of the staff have somewhat better English skills.

I'll update this review if I try other items.
Hours: Tue-Sat 9am-9pm, Sun 9am-7pm, Closed on Mondays.
CASH only.
author: Luis C.

description:
cha gio -3 stars
dry hu tieu 4 stars
added together and rounded up 4 stars

good service, nice waitstaff good coffee. There's a lot of competition in the area and it's hard to go wrong. Them Ky doesn't really stand out to me but it's still pretty darn tasty.
author: Misha T.

description:
Loooooong overdue review. But this is THE SPOT to go to when the fam and I are craving Viet/Chinese food.

The bf and his family have been coming here since they were kids and apparently it's been the same after 20 years. Service is quick (although they will leave you be after you order so if you're needy you have to speak UP!), well priced and always delicious. I have the same rotation of dishes (because I love them that much) so it's: Pho dac biet, vermicelli bowl w/ imperial rolls (way superior than eggrolls), bbq pork plate w/ shrimp cake (crunchy deliciousness), and LAMB CURRY w/ rice noodles or french bread (I'm kinda obsessed with lamb.. but their curry flavor is on point! plus they add in seasoned jalapeños) and as a Hispanic girl - me gusta.

What would make this place even more off the chain is if they would already have a jar of pickled jalapeños on every table (Hai Ky next door does, though they run out fast) because well, as I said before.. I need my jalapeños. But they have vinegar on the table so we usually just pickle our own.


SO basically if you want a no fuss hole in the wall that serves you great food everytime, this is the place to be. Their pho is one of my favorites, if not my favorite in the city and the broth is deep, rich and flavorful. I never need to add much hoisin and sriracha at all like most other places.
author: Tay R.

description: Love their 5 item plate, it's pretty much my go to dish. Haven't really tried anything else.
author: Anthony L.

description: Food was very good. Love that we were walked here by a stranger who saw us looking stumped outside Turtle Tower since it was closed for construction. Woo foodie central!
author: Heather R.

description:
It just isn't lunch with Sam T. until someone hurls.  We just hope it's neither one of us.  Please read review on Hai Ky Mi Gia  for reference.
http://www.yelp.com/biz/hai-ky-mi-gia-san-francisco#hrid:pfTOTfNbcCBL2XwoJdEceQ

So have you ever had your mind set on eating at one place then eating at another?  It can be disappointing and unfair to this alternative eatery and may have happened to me for this current outing to Them Ky.

I'm all geared up and ready for some noodles but really should've stuck to their rice place.  The Ho Fun plate I ordered lacked freshness and flavor.  I would have opted for the pho, but it's either hit or miss with this place and I wanted to try something new.  I should have stuck with the winner.

The combo rice plates posted on the walls are what makes me coming back for more.  I usually get the plate with grilled pork, a shrimp cake, and egg omelet  thing.  Ahhhh yeah now that would've hit the spot and made it worth walking through the grungy part of town.
author: Dan B.

description:
I would of totally missed this place if my friend didn't point it out and recommend that we go there because he had been there many times before and loved it!

This was my second time, but my first time was so longgggg ago that I forgot about this place! I just had a small meal before this so I wasn't really looking for a whole meal, but we got 2 things to share anyways.

My friend got the pho with beef balls and I got the seafood crunchy chow mein! It was soooo good, the noodles were sooo crunchy that I loved it so much! And they did not cheap out on the seafood at all! There was crab(fake), mushrooms, shellfish, fishballs, etc. and the bok choy, yumm. 

I ate a few beef balls from the friend's pho and it was tender and chewy! Yum! And for drinks my friend got lemonade and I got the Grass Jelly with coconut milk and omg it was sooooo sweet and tasty! Not too sweet, just perfect kinda sweet! What a meal, afterwards we headed to Quicklys where my friend got another drink! But I was too stuffed. 

I really recommend this place because it is family owned and they make their own stuff!

P.S- they lost our bill and so the drinks were on the house! Sweeeet!
author: Alice Z.

description:
For 3.5 stars it is out of this world. I lived in the SGV in SoCal for all my life and since moving up to the bay 6 months ago, I've been trying to find quality Asian food that reminds me of back home (which was basically Asia, relocated to a small town neighboring Pasadena). Them Ky, which I thought was a fluke, was randomly chosen by a friend based on cheapness and yelp reviews (golden rule: only go to restaurants with 3 or more stars, always). 

It's a party of six and it's a Wednesday night, but this place is full of people and the energy is great and it's loud and it the air smells like 20 Asian dishes combined, which are both indicative of any great Asian restaurant. So we get seated pretty much basically. The waitress is a little rude and is kind of in a rush, but what else would I expect in an establishment like this - I almost feel at home. Forgoing asian tradition, we all order individual dishes. I try a little of everything everyone orders. The broken rice plate is GREAT. Their pho ga is SOOOO GOOD. I had the chicken rice cooked in chicken broth served with chicken (I actually really hate chicken and pork, but c'mon, this is a staple back at home, so I had to! AND THEY EVEN GAVE ME THREE PIECES OF GIZZARDS- bless them). Honestly, their chicken is so delicious. So juicy, and delicate and most of it is dark meat = you're spoiling me with the good stuff. 

Our bill came out to about $10 per person, but that's because we were too lazy to break the left over ten and just walked away tipping them $10, so technically $8.30ish per person. I'd definitely come back here. 

Oh! Just don't try their egg noodles. It kind of sucked. And the broth was bland. Opt for their pho, instead, any kind!
author: Han P.

description:
Cheap, tasty, filling, and quick.

A nice, filling bowl of pho for about 6.50. I stick to the rare steak and meatballs. Lots of meat, good amount of pho, and tasty soup. Avg time spent during lunch is about 40 min.

Apparently the chicken pho comes with the intestines/innards/gizzards and you can order it w/o. They have an XL  bowl size which even my guy coworkers couldn't finish

Neighborhood is a bit sketch.

Metered parking all around.

CASH ONLY
author: Christina C.

description: After hitting up the Japanese Cherry Blossom Festival on Sunday, I was hungry, but most of the spots nearby were understandably packed. I was craving something light and fresh after standing in the sun watching the parade, so I asked my friend if he knew a good Vietnamese place to get bun (vermicelli noodle) and he directed us to his favorite neighborhood spot. The bun was fine, nothing different than you can get anywhere else, but overall the place is cheap, really casual, the people are nice and they have pictures of almost every meal on the wall! :)
author: Francesca L.

description:
FOOD/DRINK:
1.) Bun Bo Hue = Yummy. It's tame, not super spicy, but just mildy spicy to fit my mood tonight. 
2.) Lemon Soda = omg I know I've had this before, but this was perfect for my craving for a nice cold refreshing drink... ahhhhh*!


SERVICE:
A little bit nicer than typical pho service. hahah. 


ATMOSPHERE:
Ghetto the way I'm used to!


17
author: Angela L.

description:
I eat here all the time since I work 2.5 blocks away.

The star here is not the pho but the oxtail stew with rice.  We always refer to this place as the oxtail place.  It's probably the priciest dish, $9 something.  The oxtail is very tasty and, very often, with the right chewy texture.  The stew sauce is tomato base, sweet and just salty enough.  Pour a lot of sauce onto the rice and you will finish every bit of it.  Potato are deep fried prior to cooking with the stew.  

Other than the oxtail, I also like the Shrimp cake and BBQ Pork with rice.  The shrimp cake is light and springy.  The BBQ Pork is sweet soy sauce base and is cooked perfectly there.
author: Jay Z.

description: Coming in at Number Two as my second favorite place to Pho! Now this is what I consider authentic! My stars are for the overall menu, not just the Pho. It's good, it's affordable, and they have pictures on the wall! Alluring. MSG content is undeniable...but I've had bigger thirst attacks, so it's worth it to me.
author: Helen L.

description:
Portions were huge, but they had a good combo of chinese food and viet food. I didn't really like their Pho broth, but that's just me. 

3*'s for being pretty standard, taking credit card, portion size, and friendliness!
author: Arcee X.

description:
It should be a 3 1/2 star restaurant but I just had to bump it up to 4 because of their service, promptness in bringing the food out, and attentiveness.  Plus, I think you can always find a table here without waiting.  

I had the pho here.  It's not bad.  It's definetely not the best out here in the Tenderloin.  However, if Hai ky is busy, this is a great alternative.  The soup base lacks that full brothy intensity.  I want to be able to eat a bowl of pho without adding too much ingredients.  Price is probably one of the cheapest in the area.  You can go along way here with your money. 

A great way to start out 2010!!!
author: jason g.

description:
I used to go here all the time when I lived in Upper Tenderloin Heights (aka Lower Nobb Hill). Always got the pho or bun. Good stuff.

Haven't been there is awhile, but reading some of these reviews I wonder if things have changed. I'm somewhat sensitive to MSG and never got an MSG headache eating here. Now that Ethiopian place on Haight St, Axum . . . I stumbled out of there in tears.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Just for the Cha Gio & Bi Cuon (#4), this place deserves 4 stars. I'm a total imperial roll & spring roll fan. So when I had this appetizer, which is basically an imperial roll inside a spring roll, I was in love. It's so unique. Never had it anywhere else before. 

The rest of the food (pho, bun, riceplates) are pretty ordinary. Portions are big though, so that's a plus.
author: Marti L.

description:
Just enormous portions!  I had the beef brisket stew in tomato sauce served with rice.  The beef was a bit tender but the sauce was quite good.  Hubby had the BBQ pork chop over rice with a fried eye.  He said the pork chop was a bit thin.  Each dish was only $6 and no wait on a Sat night.  

it seems authentic just for the fact that they serve French bread with certain dishes.  

Huge plasma TV.
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Whenever my family has a special occasion, we usually go out to eat here, and we've been here a LOT. 

The reason why we keep coming back is because it's cheap and it's filling. Noodle dishes, rice plates, and dry noodle bowls are large portioned and less than $7-$8. Our most recent visit for our family of 5 was only ~$40, with an order of 2 large pho bowls, 2 rice plates, and 2 noodle dishes. 

Although the pho bowls are huge and filling, they aren't amazingly delicious, and sometimes require a bit more hot sauce and soy sauce to further enhance the flavor. This can be placed on the dry noodle bowls as well. The rice dishes, however, are not bad, and the beef is usually marinated well. 

The fried noodle dishes are offered with either Chow Mein (which is thin yellow noodles) or Ho Fun (which are the thick white noodles). Last time, we ordered one of each. We were given the choice of either "dry" or "with gravy", and for both we chose the "dry." Both dishes were good, but I recommend having the Chow Mein with gravy, because the "dry" noodles were bland. 

The decor is clean and has been remodeled in the last 2 years, and they've added pictures of dishes on the walls, which could be great marketing. 

The tapioca drinks are cheap, ranging from $1.85 to $2.30 depending on what flavor you get. On my last visit, I bought a mango flavored drink, and I could not be more disgusted. The tapioca was too soft, and the drink was way too sweet. I had to dilute the whole drink with a cup of water to make it drinkable. -1 star. 

Some disadvantages: 
- Servers are not as polished - language barrier, forgetting an order sometimes
- Parking is a hassle on nights and weekends, there are a few meters around there and in front
- Cash only, as is a lot of Vietnamese dishes
author: Vivian L.

description:
Them Ky, I love you, but you're bringing me down...

This place is pho-translescent. That's a made up word that implies heaping, steaming bowls of pho full of salt and MSG and beef juice. When I want mean, brassy pho I come here. When I want dainty, oxford educated pho I go around the corner to Turtle Tower and eat with the white people.

They have a pretty broad menu beyond pho, which I often ignore due to my chronic pho-deficiency. Worth trying though-the catfish, for instance, is fabulous. Also, the banh mi are grilled to order and both cheaper and dramatically better than Saigon Sandwich. Don't tell anyone.

The neighborhood is a little crusty so I recommend lunchtime.

 It's not the cleanest place but the staff is adorable and fast.
author: EDW L.

description:
Only tried one dish so my review might change if I go back and try something else.  The Combo Clear Noodle Broth looked appealing based on the picture of it on the wall and in the menu.

But it was so bland.  The shrimp was overcooked and not even fully peeled.  The squid was as well and the fish cakes were kinda fishy (not in a good way).  There were also chicken pieces that looked really unappetizing so I left them. The cellophane noodles were meh and the dish overall was nothing I ever had at a Vietnamese restaurant before.

I really wanted to like my dish ... but maybe the key is to try something more mainstream.  Like the pho.
author: F. P.

description:
you know they have 

BÁNH BÔT CHIÊN TRÚNG

But I guess no one knows! it's really good here if you can't travel all the way out to TK noodles. 
I'm not a big fan of pho. but it's okay. AT is. 
Bun bo hue IS good here. To bad they don't have banh canh cua or else I would of been more happy. lolol.
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
I came here for lunch with my mom.  I ordered the pho "train" or the xe lua.  The portions at this place was pretty good.  They were busy so service was not great.  For example, we didn't get our ice water.  Not super spectacular but not bad.  This is certainly not my first or last time at this place.  

I must say though, I do miss that Pacific Bowl place where Bodega is right around the way.  It's a shame that they are gone.
author: Andrew L.

description: I love this place. My Viet friend introduced me. All the food I've had is great but I always get the rice vermicelli bowl. The shrimp chip salads or Chinese pancakes are good to start.
author: Joe S.

description: A good Vietnamese restaurant in Little Saigon = 3.5 stars!  The food is average but the service here is great!  They take custom orders/special requests but won't charge you extra for special orders like other restaurants usually do.  We ordered the pork and egg roll over vermicelli but replaced the vermicelli with vegetables. It was delicious and well-portioned. We wanted a vegetable dish but didn't find one we liked so the lady asked us what type of vegetables we wanted in the dish. She custom made our dish with all the variety of vegetables  we wanted...what great service!  The prices are cheap and the menu is extensive. I'll definitely come again to support this mom and pop shop!
author: Angela F.

description: I had been there lots times.I like there.vietnam rice noodle and Chou ,beef Chou fen are all very delicious !
author: H S.

description:
if you desire gourmet dining, don't come to them ky. if you desire cheap eats, come here.

most dishes in the $7 range, pho (6) and rice plates (6.50)

sampling:
- hot & sour beef, pork  noodles soup (6.45)
*sliced pork feet?, sliced beef, and yes pork blood! this place is authentic. lots of meat byproducts in this yummy broth. the broth was red colored but not too hot. (still worked up a sweat though!) not a lot of msg.

takeouts:
-sundays are good, no need to feed the meters. 
-fast friendly service
-decor is retro chinatown, the '80's, none like this in oaktown now.
(chairs, tables old, but functional). pics of food offerings all over the walls.
author: Victor G.

description:
Ordered Take out.
Nothing special, I might try again,
Extra Large Pho Special was ok.
I gotta try the others in the area first.
author: vin t.

description:
Not bad for the price and service.  The menu is huge and has a selection of chinese and vietnamese fast food type dishes.  I got eggplant and fish- nom nom. 

I don't discriminate, I like this place and would eat here again for realz.
author: Skye W.

description: The pho and portion sizes are great. beef stew is ok. the seafood is not so great here. I usually just stick with the pho ga. service is hit or miss depending on how busy it gets.
author: Collin L.

description:
I am no Pho expert and don't pretend to be but I have had Pho that actually changed my mood before and made me tingle with joy. 

This Pho was just soup. I prefer the kind of Pho where after you taste the broth it's so good you don't want to add very much to it, this was the kind where you have to put everything in it including hot sauce to give it any flavor. The chicken was pretty succulent and not rubbery at all, I will give them credit for that. 

I came here on the suggestion of a friend that just came back from four months in Argentina and I guess he's still in Argentina mode because we spent three hours in here hanging out and talking. The dirty looks from the staff made me a little uncomfortable, not that I blame them, but I didn't want to force my friend to get up. At one point I stood up and instead of taking the hint he just brought up a new subject and kept talking. Finally we'd taken so long with our lunch I told him I had to go to meet people for dinner; which wasn't a lie. It was a good visit though because we had a lot of catching up to do.
author: Manny F.

description: One of the only places in Little Saigon that actually uses charbroiled pork in their Banh Mi.
author: Brandon L.

description: I went here today with my auntie and we had some vegetarian deep-fried appetizer which were really good, very crunchy.  And I had the fish and garlic eggplant for at least the second time and it was awesome.  I also go the iced coffee with condensed milk and they brought me an extra container of hot water.  They brought me a free soup and also a free jello desert but I was just too full.  I love Them Ky and I love the staff.   of my favorite places in for low-priced food that is incredibly delicious. l'll probably go back in a week or two.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
A hiddem gem in Little Saigon, Them Ky serves really amazing and authentic Vietnamese/Chinese food. The portions are huge and every dish I've tried so far has been delicious. Some of my favorites are the slow cooked ox tail (get it with the bread instead of rice on the side.. great for dipping) and the chicken salad. The pho is good but the broth is a little salty for my taste.

I used to go religiously to turtle tower around the corner but Them Ky has more options and their service is much better. Unlike many places, they use real red beans in their Che Ba Mau instead of kidney beans (gross). Overall, It's not the prettiest restaurant but the food and the drinks are legit.
author: Natalie N.

description:
On a sunny yet windy cold day, Pho is good.  In fact, on a rainy wet cold day, a hot summer day, or a cool warm night, pho is always good.  Pho is the all time stable.  But the dificult thing is to find one that is good.  Then there's the tenderloin, coined "little saigon" that supposedly offers the culture and variety of vietnamese influenced restaurants.  With about 10 pho available shops in a 1 block radius, it becomes hard to choose that one good spot.

Luckily, Them Ky is located next to the best chinese/vietnamese restaurant Hy Kam Kai, and together, these two spots make up for lunch choices in the area.

# 19 (usually the #1 everywhere else) does not dissapoint.  It comes with a good amount of bun (noodles) and plenty variety of meat, especially plenty of shiny red rare steak (if you put it on the side) as it is best served like that.  The broth is also really good as it is perfectly sweet in a aromatic flavor.  I'll definitely be coming back here sometime.
author: Vincent K.

description:
This is a great place to eat at when I have the time to trek from the Financial district over to the Tenderloin. My favorite order is #19 XL Combination Pho with beef on the side. What's great about the soup is the broth and the lack of MSG. At other restaurants you will taste the blandness of the soup or end up with a dry mouth because they put way too much MSG. Only order the #19 if you're really hungry because it's HUGE and even I have a hard time finishing it up. Eat slowly :). I also recommend the Thai Iced Tea with Tapioca or one of the cold drinks behind the counter. The red bean paste or the tapioca ones are really good. 
One downside is that it takes a while to get here via Muni (38 Geary is a pain because of traffic on Market St.) but when you time it just right you'll make it there in one piece. I highly recommend that you take public transportation or a cab there and I don't suggest walking because you will be passing by some weirdos and prostitutes. Street parking is metered so make sure you bring some pocket change to feed the meter.
author: Tim G.

description:
The first time I came here I was excited to go to my fave Pho Tan Hoa, only to find in horror that they decided to shut earlier than their ridiculously early 7pm one Sunday! In a fit of panic, I searched desperately for the nearest Pho restaurant I could find that was open, and hence walked through the door at Them Ky. I must have been pretty hungry desperate cos I thought the pho was pretty OK/good. So good that I suggested it as a venue for a group of 30 pho eaters (the Phonatics).

This next occasion, I ordered the Pho ga, as I took my first sip of broth, I realised my error.

Broth - this was really weak, it tasted like broth made from a stock cube with lots of black pepper. The chicken broth is usually more delicate than the beef. However I tried the beef one too and it lacked the meaty and star anise goodness that I crave.

Noodles - pretty decent, not too mushy

Meat - actually the chicken was pretty good. tender, fair distribution of white and dark meat and they left the skin on too :) 

Not the worst bowl of Pho I've ever had, but not in the same league as Pho Tan Hoa. I can't comment on the other dishes, and some of them do look tasty in the photos they have on the wall.

The service was very good for a whole in the wall, they were very accommodating given the large group size and the fact that we had a gorilla singing telegram join us in the middle of dinner.

Overall, I don't think I'll ever come back here for Pho, even if Pho Tan Hoa is shut, I'll try one of the other "late" opening Pho places in the area like Pho 2000.
author: Jeremy H.

description: 2.5stars for the chicken bahnmi from here.  The chicken kind of tasted like from a Lemongrass chicken dish.  The sauce was too overpowering and could have used more daikon.
author: C A.

description: Food, price,and service is good enough to bring me back as a regular.  I come for the pork chop dish#80 and coconut grassjelly drink.
author: Jayla K.

description:
I am a pho-natic (get it?) and oh boy.. this is a good one. Always fresh and always a good bowl.  I like that their menu is fairly complete for a pho joint, although I can never get myself to order anything else.. My friends liked it though.

I have to agree with some reviewers here; the broth is not as rich in itself, but nevertheless, one of the best spots in the city. 

Wish they were open later!
author: greg s.

description:
This is a low 4, so I can see how it's a 3.5.

Eggplant with fish come in a tasty sauce and with white rice. The fish is probably tilapia or some other inexpensive fish, but is tender and goes well with the sauce. And the price is right, $7.

The soda chanh is a can of club soda and a glass with lemon juice and sugar. Be sure to mix it well, but it's a good combination.

No ambiance, but you knew you were coming here for the food, didn't you? Lots of food porn on the walls to help you make your selection (or to make it harder since everything looks so good).
author: Charles B.

description:
This place often gets overlooked since they're located right next to the more popular Hai Ky Mi Gia.  There's no flashy signage to catch your eye.  This is simply a hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese restaurant.

The Mother loves coming here for their banh trang (rice paper) platter.  For about $8, you get a huge platter of cha gio (fried spring rolls), seasoned meat and shrimp balls, and a ton of bean sprouts, mint leaves, cucumbers, picked carrots, lettuce and vermicelli noodles, to wrap with rice paper.  It's a total hands-on experience, so be sure your hands are clean before you dip your rice paper into the hot water!

I was really disappointed with their bun bo hue (spicy beef noodle soup).  The soup was lukewarm, the beef had that unfresh rainbow-like sheen, and the pork blood was overcooked.  Gross.  I'm still in search of great bun bo hue in the City...recommendations, anyone?

Them Ky's got a huge menu to choose from, but if you're really undecided, just pick from the picture menu on the wall.  It will make life much easier.  And of course they post pictures of their most popular dishes.  We chose the yummy-looking beef-wrapped onions dish and it was really good.  Prices are cheap and portions are generous.  I'll be back for their supposedly good pho next time.
author: Diane L.

description:
Are you pho real?!?  This place is absolutely awful.  And that's not just from a vegetarian perspective.  I purposely dined with a carnivorous friend because of all the rave reviews for their meat dishes.  I should've listened when he said he'd been here previously and thought this place was nothing special--like a dime-a-dozen, hole in the wall joints you see in Chinatown.  Then, I thought, "Hey, Yelpers don't lie.  I've been steered towards some great restaurants.  Despite its shabby looks, Them Ky's received great reviews."

Yelpers done did me wrong this time.

Eggs had bits of shell left in it, and the imperial rolls were a greasy mess, nothing fresh.  The food was bad enough that my friend took one bite of pork before deciding to pack up the leftovers, only to pass it off to a homeless person.  (Hey, beggars can't be choosers, right?)  Prices are cheap and the portions are huge, but what difference does it make if the food's so bad?  Either way, you won't be able to finish it.  

I don't know where the five stars are coming from.  But these reviewers must not have been around the corner to Pagolac, which, I believe it to reign supreme over all other Vietnamese restaurants in Little Saigon.  Sometimes, you just have to stick with what's tried and true.  Now, I know better.  

*Cash only
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Good place to get your pho fix. The main reason I come back to this place is because of their portions and price. I usually order the x-large special beef combo (or whatever it's called on the menu...for all you pho eaters, you know what i'm talkin about)...anyways the price for this i believe was $6.95, portion is just huge and boy do they pack on that beef. I can't tell the difference between good and bad soup stock (being that i am Chinese and don't know much about Vietnamese cooking), but to me it was greatly flavorful. 

They have a big menu with many pictures on the wall of the many things they serve. I never tried anything else on the menu because i'm usually pretty hungry when i come here so I order my usual XL beef soup knowing that I will for sure walk out full and satisfied.
author: Harrison C.

description:
Sad to say this wasn't my favorite. Tried #29 - Pho w/ rare beef and beef balls. The broth was ok but it lacked complexity of flavor. Beef was a little tough actually. But it may have sat in the soup too long. The noodles were good and of course came with the requisite bean sprouts, lime slices (these were nice and fat), and fresh basil (which was plentiful). 

We came in a gigantic group of 30 people and the owners worked hard to accommodate us. They did a great job in bring out the food fast. I suppose it's just broth and noodles but they did so for a big group. Impressive.

Also tried the #43 - vermicelli with grilled pork and imperial roll. The imperial roll seemed oily than others I've had. Pork was ok, slightly tough. And while the portion was big, there wasn't enough flavor.

Oh and they are ok with BYOB. That's a plus.
author: Cindy W.

description: Remind me of the delicious cheap rice plates from my childhood.  I love the beef and tomato.  The string beans are also crispy and flavorful.  Some people like the banh mi.  Although the BBQ meat is fresh and warm, I still prefer Saigon.
author: Sue N.

description: This is the spot!!! Really good Vietnamese food in little Vietnam. Had some Ho Fun, everything else looked good too. Totally packed on a Saturday morning. We'll be back.
author: Michael C.

description:
ONLY place I can get really good Bot Chien . It's pretty much pan fried rice cake with eggs . 

Outside crispy, inside hot and gooey, a kick from the onions and it all blends together with the eggs . How much better can it get ?

You can also switch the plain rice cakes to turnip rice cakes . Also very very delicious .

And it's a HUGE plate too .

I'm getting hungry typing this .
author: Jenny Y.

description:
i used to come here all the time on the wkends with my family. duck noodles, beefball pho, charbroiled pork chops with broken rice, eggrolls, vietnamese coffee, bun, .. all good.

came here for lunch with some coworkers today. sat down, ordered, ate, chatted for awhile, all under one hour. i love -=fast service. the ladies were all very friendly too :)

i have to add an extra star bc the boss laday is super nice. every time i go here with my mom, she gives us something extra to take home... the best beef balls ever. i don't know why, but they're perfectly seasoned and perfectly bouncy too.

thumbs up: quick bite for some authentic Vietnamese -=fast cheap food. 
thumbs down: uh, so the area isn't the best..
author: Lauren Y.

description:
"I really just want to throw it up."

About five minutes after finishing dinner at Them Ky, this is what I said to my boyfriend when he asked me how I felt.  I'm pretty sure that there is MSG in the pho because I had a horrendous headache, stomach trouble and some serious thirst after having my broth (which tasted pretty darn good, by the way).

What was the problem with Them Ky?  The rare beef in my pho had freezer-burnt edges on a few of the pieces; I expect that if I'm going to have beef raw, it should still be practically mooing.  Raw AND freezer burnt ... that just seemed like a bad combination.

Just in case you are a chicken pho fan, my boyfriend said that the broth was also flavorful.  Problem is, the pieces of meat in the soup were definitely not the best parts of the chicken.  If you don't mind eating chicken and being visually reminded of the fact that you are eating a bird, don't sweat it ... you'll be fine.  :P

The fresh shrimp and pork rolls were pretty large compared to most other Vietnamese places.
