At first, I was impressed by the girth of these rolls, but after a bite or two I felt like there was too much lettuce and noodle and not enough "good stuff" that adds flavor ... needed to have less filler (hence, being as thin as most other restaurants) or most shrimp, pork and mint.  Bland, and the dipping sauce was way too thin and slimy.

Was it awful?  No, I guess not.  Did I feel like puking afterward?  Yeah, I did.  Poor tummy...

2.5 stars because the broth was that good.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Uhh-Muh-God!

Best fekkin' Pho ever!

..with all the fixins.  Of course I made mine into a muddy mess (adding Hoison Sauce, soy sauce, vinegar, lemon, lime, jalapenos, sprouts, mint, basil, hot sauce, etc (I am sure I was THE ignorant white man ~ who cares!

it was damn tasty, pho sure!
author: Mc Matty b.

description: I ordered a regular rare steak pho. They give you plenty of noodles. I was able to finish a large rare steak pho at pho garden no problem but I had a bit of trouble finishing here. The soup is better than than pho garden but I got tired of the noodles towards the end. I like how they do not use a lot of msg. They also serve boba here. Service is pretty good. The neighborhood is slightly shady.
author: Sarah C.

description:
My buddy and I originally planned to go next door to Hai Ky Mi Gia for lunch.  After weeks of my buddy talking about their tasty pho, we finally trekked out to only find the restaurant closed for vacation.  A big black gate sealed us off from our goal.  To top it off, a sickly old asian guy was making nasty gurgle noises in front of us.  Bleeeah... he pukes up next to the gate.  Damn...

We hurry next door to Them Ky seeking refuge.  The place was packed, reaping the rewards of their absent competition.  Luckily, we got a seat and ordered.  More people continued to file into the restaurant and we found ourselves moved from our 4 top table into a makeshift community table.  We didn't mind bumping elbows with strangers, since we just wanted to eat.

I got the shrimp pork rolls w/ lettuce and a large Dac Biet Xe Lua, special combo w/ rare slices of steak, well- brisket, flank tender & trips.  My buddy got the seafood ho fun.

Seemed like we were just going through the motions as our food arrived; still pondering what might have been, if Hai Ky Mi Gia was open.  The spring rolls seemed old with the lettuce turning a little.  Also I didn't enjoy the dipping sauce to go along with it.  The pho was ok.  The broth, meat and noodles were standard.  I left most of the broth in the bowl.

Maybe next time, we should order one of the dishes posted on the wall with colorful paper.  The chicken rice plate looked pretty good.  Maybe next time.
author: Sam T.

description:
This is my sister:

In Chinese: 

"Hello, Can I get 5 orders of the BBQ pork vietnamese sandwich, with the veggies including jalepenos on the side?"

20 minutes later -- arrive at Them Ky.

Screeeeeeeeech. Brake. STOP. Turn on Blinkers to double park.

Run in to Them Ky. Pay the nice owner for the sandwiches. Run out. Release Brake. Drive.

20 minutes later -- arrive at home.

Proceed to inhale the BEST BBQ PORK VIETNAMESE SANDWICH. 

Ever. (Had to add that in).
author: J T.

description:
Was brought here by my vietnamese friends, so of course I had a good feeling I'd have an excellent lunch. They recommended the curry chicken with bread on the side. This dish is simply awesome - so delicious. I'm a bit unsure how healthy that broth is, but man did it taste great. And you dip the bread in the lemon-pepper-jalapeno on the side, then in the broth. So tasty I had to bring my husband back.

I also had chicken bun, which was very good too. You can buy your vietnamese desserts here too on the way out or whatever. Got some red rice thing - so odd but tasted great.  Prices are cheap, service meh, but overall great place to go for lunch.
author: Jen D.

description:
This place has kick ass VN food, like the kind you'd get at a street kitchen in Ho Chi Minh City. I've been there twice & thoroughly enjoyed it. Not to HCMC, but to Them Ky. I've been to HCMC once. Definitely never going back there again. Something to do with sex tourism, 13 million people and a Gucci store. Ask me about it later if you really want to know.


Anyway, the food there is authentic and delicious. Cheap. Never paid more than $20 for 2 people and we left food on the plate. A good sign is that it's usually filled with Vietnamese (ok, that's an assumption on my part: they look "asian" and speak "vietnamese").

I haven't tried the pho, but the folks I was with were raving about it. I had the bun: brilliant! and the tofu salad with shrimp chips: excellent! and the shredded pork and shrimp spring rolls: nice! 

On their appetizer menu, they have "radish pancake" and "taro pancake." I asked what that was and was told "Pancake made with radish or taro." Somewhere in there, there's an egg involved. I'm trying that next.


**************************

Update: I did try the pancake. Let me start off my saying that our waitress was pretty surprised that I ordered it. Yes, nice Vietnamese lady, yes, I do want the radish pancake. Then, it took like 20 minutes for them to bring it out. My eating pal was almost through his entire giganormous bowl of pho. We were guessing that they went out to get some of the ingredients to make the damn thing.

I'm not even sure how to describe this ... "pancake" ...other than to say it's made with rice flour, it's thick, it had some shredded radish in it  and some fried egg  and green onion. It's served with a yummy spicy soy-based sauce. By itself, it wasn't anything special. A little rubbery, a little chewy, a little bland. The sauce made it really snap. 

I dunno that I'll get it again. It was pretty good. Kinda weird. But there's a million other things I want to try there first.
author: Yasi S.

description:
Remember that friday a few weeks ago when the weather was TOO NICE?  It triggered allergies that triggered a migraine that triggered vertigo similar to the roller coaster ride in Great America.  In that altered state, I thought, in my infinite wisdom, that I would take a bus ride down to the heart of the tenderloin, and have a steaming bowl of Pho.  Perfectly safe, since the sun is high as those women of the night planted on the sidewalk next to a dump of poo.  

I got off the 38.  Walked down the block or two down larkin.  There was a playground that turns in to where the wild things are.  And then I saw Them Ky.

Inside, I was seated by the door.  What is up with all these places that put single diners by the door?  If we are cut do we not bleed?  If there is a draft, do we not get cold?  Well, it wasn't too bad since I get very very warm when eating pho.  And it was the perfect place to watch the crazy lady show.  

I ordered the rare steak and tendon pho.  Because I love ligaments.  As i waited, a crazy lady in a wheelchair came in, ordered 7 rolls with butter, opened every individually wrapped roll and dumped a king's ransom's worth of sugar in each roll.  All from her wheel chair, all while shouting in clipped, demanding, assertive asian language that the proprietors understood but when entirely over my head.  

My soup.  There was so much meat on this.  So much tender beef, so much tender meat.  This is the largest portion of meat on pho in my recollection.  The broth was ok.  i think.  But this opinion may be colored by my migraine/infinite wisdom.  

The people who run this are really really nice.  They are, by far, the nicest asian people serving food in a commercial setting that I've experienced.  And the prices are terrific.  Aw, what the hell, I'll give it the 5 star perfection.  where else can you get a bowl for $6?  

I'll have to go back and pay more attention to the broth.  But it's pretty darn tasty and they have much variety.

UPDATE: 07.08.09

I went back here because I'm doing this thing where I order the rare steak on the side.  And also, I'm trying to retrain the amount of basil and bean sprouts I put in to the broth.  And finally, because I'm trying to figure out which places have the deadly MSG (I'm allergic) and which places are not death.  A bit dramatic, I know.  But I've got nothing else going on in my life.  

Today, i ordered the steak and tendon.  Now, I don't know what makes places do the different slices of tendon, but I know that in the end, it does make a difference when it comes to texture and eating enjoyment.  The tendon today was not so good.  But there was a lot of it.  But it was sliced thin.  

The steak I ordered on the side.  See that?  I'm growing up.  I'm eating my pho in a deconstructed manner that would make top chef cringe.  This platter of beautiful RED RED RED RED REDRUM REDRUM!!!  steak beautiful color bright red.  It was a generous serving and it was bright red!  I mention this because i've been served "dull red" and even "red with splotches of brown!"  The things that one takes for granted, like red meat.  That is still red.

The broth was good today.  It was not the deep color of Nam something something something.  It was a clear.  And when I remembered to take a sip before corrupting it with basil, it had a singing clarity that was once reserved for small italian boys.  Next time I think I'll not put in bean sprouts because that makes the broth cool down too quickly.  And I'll ask for the broth to be xtra hot.  EXTRA hot.  I only just re-grew the roof of my mouth after a tragic Imperial Roll accident.  

The ventilation here is perfect so when i start getting meno-pausal symptoms, the cool breeze of crazy TL brings me right back to reality.
author: Christina C.

description:
Had wide noodle stir fried with vegetables and tofu. The tofu tasted old (has that old, sour taste to it). The vegetables also tasted old and dried. The canned mushroom, bamboo shoots also tasted old.

Skip this place! There are others just around the corner and down the street that are much much better.
author: Mango M.

description:
This is a great find. It's one of the most consistent Pho establishments in the city for sure with great food, friendly and efficient staff and good prices. Make sure to try their Spring Rolls...it's only the pork that's deep fried! 

It may not be in the greatest part of town or have the nicest interior to look at but if you want a good meal at a good price this is the place to go.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
So Much Variety!

I love the fact that there is so much you can choose from here. I came to San Francisco last week for vacation with my husband who is Vietnamese. The food was authentic enough for his taste and so so so much better than teh vietnamese food in NY!

The best is the special egg roll with pork bits wrapped in lettuce! To Die For!
author: D. Licious F.

description:
This review is breaking my heart.....but I got to be fair to all those other reviews that I have ever written. I really really wanted to like this place as I have yet to find my Vietnamese pho place in little Saigon. 

The pluses: Upon entry I noticed the spacious seating in the well lit room. The tea was brought out promptly and I was seated immediately by a very friendly/sweet woman who waddled around. "What to order?" I though.....might as go w/ the standard of pho since that's a pretty good determination of the quality of the food for the place. While deciding, the phone rings twice and its not that annoying phone ring...its this old school Castlevania, Final Fantasy, Legend of Zelda esque tune that brings those days rushing back. 

Pho came out after 2 mins later and it was absolutely huge. It was screaming hot so I gave it 5 mins.  

This is how I eat my pho:  
1. Put in all the sprouts, mint, peppers and lime.
2. mix
3. Drink about 2/3 of the broth. 
4. Eat the rest; savoring the goodness. 

Everything went fine from 1-3 but while drinking the broth I couldn't help thinking how salty the broth was. I shrugged it off by convincing myself that it couldn't be THAT salty.....then I started feeling my mouth getting parched and my lips cracking. Ok...this might be a little salty for me. "Lemme just finish this up." I think to myself.  The noodles...and the meat were all fine...but this broth....its really starting to hurt me head.....speaking of which...what is this condensation on my brow? Am I actually sweating?!? Is my body desperately trying to purge salt out of it? It is!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I never wast food...ever....but I get down to the last cup of the broth/salt mixture and I just can't take it any more. I'm feeling real light headed now and my heart is pounding like a hammer. I get up and pay......looking for a comment box to suggest less salt/seasoning....there isn't one. 

My head is throbbing as I go home....I actually contemplate gagging myself. Now I have eaten LOTS of things that are unhealthy but have never contemplated purging..until last night. 

If anyone from Them Ky is reading this, PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE put less salt in the pho....end. I will give it a second shot w/ a rice plate (I told you...I want to like this place), but the pho is out of the question.
author: Angelo F.

description:
Another double wide Vietnamese storefront restaurant in Little Saigon.  Tripe Pho was heartier than most, Southern style, a mass of noodles, tasty.

The menus is extensive and has lots of extra items like sandwiches, rice plates, etc.  I'll be back but it would take ten visits to review the place properly.  Prices are typical ($5 to $6 for noodel soups).  Decor is no frills basic and a little cluttered.  A lunch joint mostly.
author: Gil S.

description:
Awesome Vietnamese sandwiches!  Comparable to Saigon Sandwiches.

I usually come here for its Vietnamese sandwiches, especially the BBQ chicken or BBQ pork - freshly toasted baguette, generous amounts of pickled carrot & other veggies, and great, juicy BBQ-ed meat, all for $2.50 (no tax)!  It's a great cheap snack for now or later (still crunchy!).

Setbacks: not the cleanest restaurant, but just get the sandwich to go.  The sandwich also takes a while, at least 5 mins (they heat everything up before putting it together to give it the fresh feel/taste) so it's worth the wait.  Call in to order a sandwich if you're a in a rush, then pick it up.
author: Jason K.

description:
Only thing I like here is the Jai Gwey (rice cakes deep fried with scrambled eggs/onions) and the enormously huge portion of their Pho Dac Biet.  The pho is only average...but the enormously huge portion pushed it up a notch.  Other than that....service is slow and the lights are so dim inside the restaurant..you swear they are trying to hide some bugs in there (I saw a few cockroaches in my lifetime roaming around)

The few rice plates I had...the rice was overcooked (dried) and their menu is similar to any pho places around TL.  I'll recommend you to go somewhere else to have a better tasting experience.

Definitely a place for TAKE OUT only
author: Dave L.

description:
I discovered that this is quite a hot post-workout spot for 24-hour Fitness freaks. I've only been here once, but I can definitely vouch for taste. Though you might not order pho or Vietnamese sandwiches, and though the food won't knock the socks off of your date, it's definitely safe to add this to your list of weekly chow shacks. 

We ordered the oxtail stew and beef soup, both of which were tasty and cooked right, not to mention affordable. The spring rolls were fine, as were the shrimp cakes, all cheap. Vietnamese coffee turned out ok, but remember to ask for extra hot water, which is served in a weird contraption. Unscrew and push the center button to pour.

Obviously I need to pay several more visits to this place until I can talk about their pate sandwiches and of course the pho. Oh, these irresistible Vietnamese restaurants. You know, if the world's supply of pate suddenly ran dry, San Francisco would just shrivel up and disappear right off the map. ;)
author: Daniel C.

description:
A great place for vietnamese food.  Big bowls of pho with various cuts of meat.  

One of the best dishes is not on the menu, but on the wall.  This is a wrap dish for maybe $9 or $10.  You get a plate of flat shrimp cake, pork, imperial rolls, rice noodles, peanuts and green onions.  You get another plate with lettuce, herbs, and pickled vegetables.  You get a set of dry rice wraps that you dip into hot water, wait until they soften, fill them with a mix of the above ingredients and maybe a shot of hot sauce, roll em up, and eat them.  When you run out of the rice noodle wrap, you use the lettuce leaves as wraps.
author: John T.

description: I'm surprised this hole in the wall doesn't get better ratings. Came here on NYE with friends and boyfriend and could not leave happier! Great prices, scrumptious dishes from a wide selection, and very friendly staff. LOVE IT!!!!
author: Alex V.

description:
A little dingy but if you are into awesome Vietnamese sandwiches... well, heh heh. This is home sweet home. Take it from the folks who know best...(my south east asian friends) this place is the bomb.

Forget Lee's. This is the real deal!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
I don't see how they are different from any other Vietnamese restaurants in the neighborhood.  It's not especially good, but not bad either.  I work in the area, so I'll prob. visit from time to time.

One thing that I didn't like... They posted pics of some of their food, but I like to think that if you put pics up on the wall, they are the restaurant's specialty.  I thought you prob. can't go wrong w/ them, so I picked this pan fried clear noodle.  I didn't  like it.  that was a huge disappointment.
author: AhLin C.

description:
The restaurant was very impressive, and exceeded my expectations as well. The food was delicious. The waitress served us jasmine tea which was soothing to us, from walking around in the cold all day. 
As our appetizer my boyfriend and I decided to choose something that we both had never heard of, and that was the Chinese pancake with egg. Hands down it was delicious, by far the best choice we could have made. The appetizer was large in portion and satisfied us until our main entree's came out.  I had ordered the hot spicy beef and pork soup. I wasn't a fan of the blood sausages in the stew but other then that it was really good. The prices aren't to bad we spent about $23 for our whole meal, each plate was $5 to $8 and the sandwiches are even cheaper starting at $3. We will be back fairly soon, and I suggest anyone who is wanting to  indulge in authentic Vietnamese food to check this place out!
author: Melody T.

description:
I like the service here. The people are nice and friendly.
I do not come often, because I live in the different part of town.
And whenever I have business here I would stop by this restaurant.
I had sea food rice soup. It was very good.
They gave me gigantic bowl, I can't finished so I have it to go.
I hope you enjoy this place as much as I do.
Thank you.
author: Kim L.

description:
i have been eating at this place well over 10 years.  the food has always been consistent all this years. Within the last few years they have expanded their menu tremendously.  Another thing i think they did was post photos of dishes on the wall for customers to know what they are getting into before they order which is good for first timers.  

after they have got shut down by the city for roach infestation. ill have to pass. i will no longer eat here. they gotta keep their food prep area clean otherwise keep losing customers. sad to see the people who work here let this place fall.
author: Art N.

description:
I rarely give five stars, but I think Them Ky really deserves it!  

Maybe I caught them on a really good day, but this was my third time here and everything was still pretty much solid.  

Aside from their expansive menu and helpful pictures that adorn their walls, their service is impeccable for what is considered a Vietnamese semi-dive restaurant. And, especially for one that is situated in the TL. I don't think this place is the dirtiest, but its definitely not one of the cleaner ones. 

Anyway, the servers are always efficient, fast and friendly regardless of how busy they get.
author: Dorothy N.

description:
I read all the positive reviews and decided that since years had passed since I last tried Them Ky, I would check it out again for myself. I must say I was pleasantly surprised. Service was good, the place looked a lot cleaner in general than it used to.

I ordered shrimp Hot and Sour soup and when it came I "put my face into it" and didn't look up until I was so full I had to stop. I brought a good bit home with me and enjoyed it later that evening. I will be going back to Them Ky. I'm glad I tried it out again!
author: Marcia P.

description: I go here for lunch or pick up sandwiches on most Sundays at noon. The sandwiches are always good, that I like I took big bites. When I eat the spicy noodles,they are sometimes too spicy but I enjoy the ones that are not spicy. Most of the time there is no parking,so I usually pick sandwiches up and sometimes spicy noddles. The service is very good and the people are nice to us.
author: William Z.

description:
I've never given a 3-star rating before, but while I thought this place was interesting, and would eat here again, it didn't love it.

I seem to be on a quest for the perfect six-dollar bowl of Bún bò Hu, and this was not it. It wasn't just that it was full of 'by-products' I mean that's traditional and I could have ordered it with just beef and pork and nothing else, no?

As I've seen in several other reviews, it just didn't taste fresh. It was fair.

The place has an amusing off-beat atmosphere... Luis C. nailed it when he describes the "short handicapped woman who greets everyone with a cheerful 'hi'" She totally makes the experience.

It could have been random but there were several gay customers, both Vietnamese and not while I was there. Don't know what that's about, but cool customers.
author: BigJohnS F.

description:
The menu, when seen from outside, seems only to have 13 items.  one looked good, so decided to take a try.  Upon seating, got a bigger menu, but not by much as far as vegetarian stuff goes.  Still, the vege-ham and tofu looked good outside so I order that.  Its kinda bland.  I don't know if that's how they roll and just expect you to use more of the sauces, but I needed more than usual.  I usually don't like to put too much on and let the dish speak for itself.

Still, it was ok, filling (good portion for cheap) and staff was friendly.  I'd go again if I were around here and felt like this specific dish again.
author: Nessie V.

description: To keep it short, this is a decent beef pho restaurant. Their menu items includes noodle soup items that contains tripe, which is my focus. Decor is so so, but then so is Turtle Tower around the corner which seems to be the favorite for restaurants around here mainly emphasizing on pho.
author: H K.

description:
Been frequenting this place, when in town, since the mid-90's. Small, no-frills Viet joint with a few tables and a super nice staff. Excellent BBQ beef, pork, & chicken baguettes and rice plates. Very easy on the pocket...walk in with $10, walk out bursting at the seams.

Am I the only one that enjoys the sketchy jelly-green roots drinks at Viet joints? Do you wonder what the hell they put in them yet secretly dig them too?
author: NaN K.

description:
CHEAP! 
BIG PORTIONS!! 
TASTY!!! 

the ma and pa version of TK Noodles [for those of you who know what that is]. it's a Vietnamese-Chinese place. i didn't really noticed what chinese dishes they had to offer, but there's a long list of vietnamese food. 

i LOVED the banh bot chien - just like mom makes! the noodle bowl was good; i couldn't finish it. lots of meat! however, the quality of meat isn't so great. not organic for sure. nor foster farm! the kind you see on sale at Safeway for 99cents a lbs. 

i agree, cleanliness might be an issue here. it's a decent good cheap eat for every now and then.
author: Jocelyn T.

description: I guess I'm kind of a regular here, their food is really good and very affordable. Yes it doesn't loom the best, and its obviously not in the best neighborhood. But Omg! Their seafood soup is so darn good. I always get it! I really want to try other thongs cause everything looks so good but, I can't help but to order my fav noodle soup. I also get their pan fried taro with egg which is another goodie! Oh! Don't forget to try their fish and bean sprouts over rice. Their portions are really big too!
author: Taylor W.

description:
Another great find in this neighborhood walking distance to Farmers Market and the Library.  Sunday routine just got a whole lot tastier.

Yummy pho.  No frills so didn't get the usual condiments that we expected.  On a whim, we ordered the fishcake that another table enjoyed, and it was good stuff.

Some wait, but there are enough tables to move the crowd.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Different restaurants belong in different categories...this place belongs in the hole in the wall/dive category where you get cheap, satisfying food with not many other frills.  (Even tho they recently remodeled a bit more and looks better.)  Another good sign is the amount of Vietnamese and other Asian regulars in here.  I'm assuming some of the non-Asians come up from the courthouse/city hall/ federal building/ main library/ civic center area....I could be wrong.

Big portions, affordable prices and friendly service.  The Pho will make ANYONE full but I prefer the rice dishes more.  I like the Eggplant and Fish dish or the Buon Chay Gio Thit Nuong (one of those cold vermicelli noodle dishes with meat, shrimp cake and an eggroll).  They have nice pictures of the food on the wall now (items not necessarily found on the regular foldout menu).  Ive seen a few new items on the wall.

Their appetizer rolls (quite large) and Banh Mi sandwiches are good too.  I order the ham sandwich combo special usually.

I also like a couple of their Vietnamese cold  specialty drinks found in that front refrigerated display shelf.  Nobody has said anything about their drinks....I think theyre good. 

All in all,  a respectable place with good value.  If you're picky about your food, this place has a huge menu.
author: Gilbert C.

description:
This is a really random hole in the wall place in the Vietnamese area of the TL. 

Its the typical Vietnamese fare, with some Chinese food in there for good measure. And of course they have the mandatory pictures of the food on the wall that highlights any classy Vietnamese joint. The food and the prices were good. I had the Pho with all the yummy nasty bits (that seems to be overlooked by the whities, haha) and it was good. The soup had good flavor, meat was good, and noodles were springy. It was filling as fuck too.

My friend had the onions wrapped in roasted beef rolls, and it tasted great too!

All in all, with tip and tax, 20 bucks. Good deal! Shady area though. Don't get shanked!
author: Rocky K.

description:
Ordered bun bo hue here. Big portion. not as spicy as other places. Noodles are terrific. 
however, be careful with your car and walking there, lots of s4%^@t on Ellis street, also saw a homeless guy eating off a compost bin just steps away from the restaurant.
author: godzilla m.

description: Seafood Chow Fun.  Nuff Said Son!
author: Jamal M.

description: Them Ky is the real deal:  gritty Vietnames dive in the TL.  This is why we live here.  Food is great, it's cheap and I think vetting it down to granular detail like a Ruth Reichl review of Michael Mina is ridiculous.   These Yelpers - geez, knowwhati'msayin?   Greasy?  Of course it's greasy - it's supposed to be.  $6 for BBQ pork, Imperial roll over vermicelli noodles: neighborhood street food.  And very good street food at that.
author: Sam C.

description:
Food usually cold and stale.  Too much MSG.  Used to go there almost weekly but stopped because often felt sick after eating there.  Really wanted to like this place because the ladies there are nice.  Maybe will give it another try.

Update:
Went back.  Food even worse.  That's the last visit here.  Too bad.
author: Bob S.

description:
I like to judge places like these by judging the people who come there.  Fact is - I don't know much about Vietnamese food, but look around when you're there - the people there in the restaurant are 90% vietnamese and there's a big family vibe about the place.

It's not the most glamorous, but the food is yummy and the people aren't trying to be pretentious.  I appreciate that.  My partner and I eat there all the time and almost always enjoy it.
author: Daniel H.

description: Overrated. Worth exactly three stars. Far superior places available as close as next door.
author: Sven S.

description: By far the best 5 items rice plate I have ever eaten!  I didn't give them a 5 star due to the decor, it looks old and run down but the food is great and at an affordable price.  You can choose from bbq pork, bbq chicken or bbq beef for the 5 items.  The food is consistent and I never had a bad meal.  Just make sure you have an appetite because it is a huge portion and once finished you will fall into food coma.  Located in the so call Tenderloin but nothing to be alarmed about.  Never had a problem eating there.  Just make sure you are ready to find parking because it can be difficult due to all the traffic around there.
author: James L.

description: quite different...vietnamese cuisine...hot spicy pork and pork blood soup....slight tang and sweaty spice....not the standard simple pho joint....dive fish cake and clear noodle saucing joint...claypot catfish, eggplants, bbq pork, beef stew, pho, etc....
author: Hen A.

description: Order #2 with broth on the side and a side of chinese donuts, then dip a piece of donut into the broth and put it in your mouth, then dress up your bowl with whatever you desire: sriracha, chili, pepper, jalapeno, soysauce, vinegar, mix it around and take a bite...YUMMMMM!
author: Oanh N.

description: I grew up with this place and they are always reliable to go to.  They have so many different dishes and types of noodles that you will never get bored.  The food is clean, and also very good!  The customer service is excellent, and the price is also pretty cheap.  My favorite place to go for Vietnamese Noodles and other dishes.  Try it out!  You won't regret it.
author: Bernie C.

description: This place gives you biggggg portions, I like it here. Easy to find parking, go on sunday so meters will be free. Service is nice. I ordered the BBH, and it's not bad, of course I had better but the meat make up for it, my friend had the regular pho and it was hugeeee. Also the house salad is very special. Good Price, one of the best pho place in TL.
author: Sandy L.

description:
Found this place out of chance, and it's the only Vietnamese spot I go out of my way to eat at. I'm am by no means a Vietnamese food connoisseur, but I've got a thing for this place. 
My regular order: Spicy Chicken Over Rice
yeah, it might not stick out on the vast menu, but goddamn is it tasty. Served with a hefty side of white rice, it consists of thinly sliced chicken sautéed with a mix of veggies, most of which i can't think of the names of at this moment.
bottom line, It's a damn good and spicy dish, and it'll fill you up.
Their tea is perfect for the meal. 
AND it's cheap.
If you're looking for good Vietnamese food in the TL, head over to Them Ky.
author: Q M.

description: Here's another great Vietnamese restaurant in the tenderloin district, or AKA, "Little Saigon."  I was craving for bun bo hue and so I thought I'd check this place out with a friend right after work. It was early, around 6:30pm on a weekday and the place seemed pretty empty with a few occupied tables. I like how they have pictures of their items on the menu, making ordering a bit easier, but then again, it makes me want to order multiple dishes, more than I can feast on! So I ordered the bun bo bue for $6.95 and my friend ordered the seafood noodle soup. Our order was taken by a very sweet and lovely grandmother. As soon as we sat at the table, she asked for our order, when we told her we needed a few more mins, she came back a few more mins, and then while we were enjoying our food, she'd come by to check to make sure we were doing alright and if we needed anything else. I wish she was my grandmother. This restaurant definitely has a "family owned" feel to it. Anyway, I really liked my bun bo bue. I got a very large bowl, and I believe I asked for a small. Although I also asked for it to be spicy, it wasn't spicy enough. Next time I'll ask for extra spicy. As for my friend, his bowl of seafood noodle soup looked good, but he said he got a stomach ache after that. I'd definitely be back!
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
i was aiming to go to hai ky mi gia, but they were out on vacation. perhaps it was a blessing in disguise. be warned: the amazing review might be a result of my fairly newfound appreciation for vietnamese food.

i ordered a vegetarian fried rice and a vegetarian pho. oh. my. god. the vegetables in both of the dishes were similar, and they worked so well together. please tell me this is msg-free. and if it's not, lie to me. it's so delicious.
author: Jamie C.

description: I got FOOD POISONING from there. That was a year ago. I haven't forgot about it. It was my first time ever getting it. I'll never go there again. I should have known better. I had ordered the verimcelli noodles. I believe it was the sauce that came with it that was hella old and or contaminated. I called the health department on them, didn't know if that did any good. They're still open. I guess not The restaurant on the corner is a little different but way better and its Fresh!
author: E W.

description: We order take out from here allot for lunch where I work with mostly Vietnamese and Filipino mechanics, I'm the only white guy. I wasn't afraid to try the Ox tail, and you shouldn't be either. It is delicious! I'll definitly continue to eat here. The Pho is good too, and you get so much noodles, it's impossible to finish it all in one sitting! (well, at least impossible for this white guy)
author: Jevir G.

description:
We tried Them Ky after consistently seeing the long lines forming during lunch time while we dined across the street at Vietnam II.  

We finally took the plunge and ate there last weekend.  Strangely, there were no lines anymore, and the place wasn't even totally full.

Though the food is pretty good, I guess we felt let down that it wasn't spectacular.  Just good, solid, Vietnamese food at very good prices.  Certainly nothing you can't get at any number of places in Little Saigon. 

But this place does have low prices, maybe a bit lower than average, even for Vietnamese food.  If you're on a budget, you'd probably give this place 5 stars.
author: Dave N.

description: I can't believe I forgot to mention this last time: THEIR SANDWICHES!!!  The five stars are for the bbq beef sandwiches.  Basically, if you like the meat that comes in a vermicelli bowl, you'll definitely like these sandwiches.  They take that same bbq meat, either pork or beef, and they stuff it into bread along with the regular pickled carrots and some peppers. No frills otherwise, but oh-so-delish.  My friend calls them "crack sandwiches."  If I could, I would eat these for lunch every day. The only one time I had a problem with them, out of ordering them 40+ times, would be this one time when the meat was extra salty. Other than that, I love em!  (They also do chicken and vegetarian, I think.)
author: ML N.

description:
From the outside this is just another Vietnamese place in the Tenderloin.  Unless you drive right up to the door you will almost certainly walk past a few others on your way and wonder whether you would be just as well off stopping in one of those.  Though I haven't visited them all I can with great confidence say keep on going.  Them Ky is some great eating!

Let's start with the service and setting.  The range of Vietnamese restaurant choices in the area go from somewhat chichi to dive and this place is definitely on the dive side of the scale.  But within that context the service is entirely fine and the place is totally clean.  No deductions there.  So then it becomes all about the food.  For the most part you will find the similar menu options at many places throughout the city but this one also has Vietnamese sandwiches and in general has an extensive menu.  I tend to use Pho Hoa (the one on Clement) as my base level of decent pho as for years it was in the rotation of fallback plans for any evening where the dinner decision was a struggle.  From there I had on several occasions tasted worse and somewhat better pho.  But from the first taste of the broth at Them Ky I knew I was on a whole new level!  It had a rich, full color and flavor.  And that was before I spiced it up with jalapenos, sprouts, basil, lemon and ceracha sauce (all of which was very fresh).  My friend ordered and loved the tofu salad with shrimp chips and we also had the shredded pork and shrimp rolls which were very fresh and tasty.  Add in that 2 of us ate, with something to drink and a nice tip, for ~$20 and Them Ky ends up being fantastic!
author: Jay W.

description:
I've been going here for almost 10 years. It's an insitution for the neighborhood. After awhile I come here for only 4 items on the menus because they are freaking delish! All the other plates are pretty good but nothing to rave about. My top 4 items are:

Pho Dac Biet- One of the best in the city, flavorful, not too strong, not too weak. They have all my favorite meat toppings and the pho noodles come out just right. Not too hard or too soft.

Bun Bo Hue- The spicy pork soup is yummmmmy! I love the thinkly slice cabbage, lime, and herb condiment that it comes with. You get thinly slice pork and blood cubes. If you didn't grow up eating it then it won't be for you. You can ask for it w/o and save them some money on waste. I tried bun bo hue in other restaurants but this is one of my favorite.

BBQ Meat (of your choice), shredded pork, and eggloaf over rice- A wonderful dish if you want to get full. I love it because of the variety on the place. Comes with the sweet, garlic, lime-chili dipping sauce and sliced cucumbers and tomatoes.  You can also get it with grilled shrimp or pork chop and egg rolls.

Lastly I love the grilled chicken over rice. Deliciously marinated and grilled hot and served over rice with dipping sauce and pickled carrots and diakon. If you love chicken this is the dish for you! Another variation I like is the steamed chicken over rice that comes with ginger oil. You can drink that stuff! No kidding!

There's 3 hostesses... which other ppl already covered so I won't do that here. If you are looking for a good meal at decent prices. Try one of the dishes above. Once you have favorites it's hard to order anything else!
author: Kent K.

description: I really hate this place.  I am a creature of habit, so I will usually go to restaurants to only order my favorite dish.  So if Them Ky were only a pho place, it would be great because they have great great pho.  BUUUTTTT their other dishes are equally as magnificent!  Really good vermicelli noodles, vietnamese sandwiches,  and their other daily specials are spectacular.  I haven't tried them all but i have tried enough to come to the conclusion that you honestly can't go wrong with this place.  I was going to give them 4 stars, but there is this awesome server lady there that remembers how I like my pho every time (combo bowl with no tripe, extra tendon), so 4.5 stars.
author: Chris C.

description: I have been wanting to try this place out for a few months now but have always gone instead to my usual haunts like Vietnam II and Turtle Tower.  I finally went there.. not once but twice in a week!  Love their pho.  Meat is cut so thin and served nice and raw. (other places hand you a bowl of meat that's already way overcooked).  The soup was nice and flavoorful.  However, the big thing is the price is cheaper than the ones nearby!  Throw in nice quantity and now I'm hooked.  I also went on Saturday with family and my sister tried the sandwiches.  Lots more meat in their sandwiches than Lee's.  Service is prompt but cash only.  Now one of my new favorite places to eat lunch during the week.
author: Wayne C.

description: The pho here is good--one of the few I approve of in the city so far.  Sucks that they don't take card, so the place across the street gets my business when I'm too lazy to go to the ATM.
author: Tokki M.

description: Get the green tea "yoka's" (tapiocas). We are there almost daily and the yoka's are only 2 bucks!
author: Al W.

description: I Love this little hole in the wall place!  This place not only  offer good value for your money but  also serve one of the best Pho by very friendly staffs.
author: Will T.

description: The food here is not really good, not too bad.  It does the job when it comes to something quick especially after 6pm when most restaurants in this area are closed.
author: Lily K.

description:
i really really like their pho. maybe it's because i was raised on chinese-style soups that are meant as a palate-cleanser, as opposed to heavy american soups (which are tasty in their own way but very different), but this is one of the only pho places i've been where the broth is just right. the noodles weren't anything special except that it was cheap and there were lots of them, but the meat was excellent and, most importantly, the broth tasted real. it's the kind of broth you can drink without feeling super thirsty from salt and msg afterward. yum.

boyfriend got some kind of barbecued meat over rice (beef rolls i think), and that was delicious as well. i really liked their fish sauce-- tangy, spicy, not too sweet. even if it weren't dirt cheap, and if the service wasn't prompt and super friendly, it would be a solid 4.
author: Dana D.

description: This is the very first vietnamese place that I ever went to in the TL.  I was actually living in a hostel up the street at the time, and a roomate recommended this place to me since they apparantly served this awesome kind of vietnamese noodle soup called pho.  This wizard from the far east told me to order the combination and just wait patiently and take it back to the crib.  Well I did as merlin told me to and boy was I handsomely rewarded.  Beef balls, tripe, and many different cuts of beef in a beautifully spiced broth with some excellent and fresh herbs, vegetables, spices, and sauces that I could add at my own pace.  This is the ultimate noodle soup...better than grandmas and a sure fire cold killer when mixed with some stiff brandy drinks...geezers need excitement if their lives dont provide it they go incite violence, common sense simple common sense
author: Francis K.

description: Was looking for a pho place in the TL and happened to stumble upon this place . The place isn't exactly very clean but the food here is not bad , not bad at all . The pho is flavorful & delicious .. esp. the noodles . The shrimp cakes are good too as well as the tea that they serve . The menu has some very interesting items that I haven't seen in other pho places and that I would like to try in the near future . Don't get the eggroll shredded pork springroll ( whatever you call it ) AKA the house special spring rolls . It's basically an eggroll wrapped with lettuce and rice paper . It's creative but tastes weird . Prices are pretty reasonable . Service was okay .. the people were pretty polite .
author: Eileen L.

description: its not the fanciest restaurant or anything, but their food is pretty dang good. especially their pho soup. nom nom nom!!
author: Valerie N.

description:
my, my. i ordered a bowl of pho with beef slices and tendon. [regular size]
inside the bowl was an insane clump of noodles, i could barely finish it. 
it's worth my five/six bucks to come here and order a nice and hearty bowl of pho. 
so much noodles. i was not hungry the rest of the day. 

waiting time for a table is rather quick during lunch time. if you're willing to share a table, go for it. it's faster. if you're not willing to share a table, i'd say wait time is about five to fifteen minutes. 

wandering for a big meal in the tenderloin? visit them ky. highly affordable. large portions.
author: Court L.

description: I eat at this place because it's "family style" meaning no pretensions. The food dishes are all in photos on the walls or pictures in the menu. The prices are fair and pretty comparable to restaurants around that area of "Little Saigon" (on Ellis street between Larkin and Polk). I eat there about three to five times per week and since I am a 'regular' customer, I can substitute items on the plates.  For example, even though eggs are mixed in with the radish pancakes, I always get an extra two fried eggs on the side. The place can be ear shattering during lunch time, but very mellow after 1 PM.  I love their tofu soup they serve on the side of your main rice dish, but I get one regardless of what dish I am having since I do eat their often. You can get one on the week days only. Also you can have ice in your tea if you ask. The freshly made desserts are a plus an are to be savored slowly for full taste.
author: Tamara C.

description: the imperial rolls and sandwiches are unghghgh so gooood, and the pho is consistently good comfort food when you're sick or even when you're well.  my favorite staff person is the shortest lady who waddles around and abruptly barks out each food item as she puts them down on the table.
author: Katherine K.

description: my favorite banh mi thit nuong (vietnamese sandwich) place .. better than Saigon's or Lee's .. the meat actually tastes like it's been grilled instead of microwaved ... surprising since this place doesn't specialize in sandwiches .. I'm so happy I found a place that serves sandwiches that taste good AND don't make my stomach hurt!
author: Anvy A.

description: slurp-slurp, chomp-chomp - piping hot pho, generous rice plates and great crunchy banh mi sandwiches. i love it here the cute little waitress is so friendly, food is quick and cheap; great place to come the day after a night of hardcore drinking. i swear pho cures hangovers.
author: Kristina L.

description: damn this place was good. ordered the 5 item rice plate thing  which consisted of fried shrimp cake, egg roll, steamed egg loaf, bbq grilled beef, and shredded pork--yea i got greedy and wanted a little bit of everything =]. i almost killed the whole thing too! for 9 bucks i'd say this was well worth it!
author: josephine n.

description: hands down the best pho in the city. period.
author: Az A.

description: Hrmmm, not really sure how this got such a high rating...i'd give it 2.5 stars or so.  My girlfriend and I went here last night after reading the reviews and walking past pagolac and not wanting to wait because of the area these places are in.  So off to turtle tower we went.  Get inside...seems kinda dirty and was pretty empty.  Oh well, been to hole in the walls that were dirty and often its the best food...didn't seem to be the case here.  We both got the flank and rare beef pho, and an order of the beef/shrimp rolls.  The flank meat was almost completely fat in one giant string that was pretty much in-edible.  The broth was ok, but the soup wasn't particularly hot, which made it hard to eat a whole lot of.  They were kinda skimpy too on the vegetables they gave us for our soups.  The rolls were rather dry which made them kinda hard to eat as they just felt kinda grainy once you started chewing them.  maybe we got the wrong thing, I dunno but it definately didnt seem 4 star worthy.  :[
author: Brett T.

description: This place looks a little suspect, but it is good!  We were headed for turtle tower, but came here for a slightly shorter wait time.   We both had pho and it was really good.  The service was quick, but the tables were cramped and we barely had enough room for all the dishes we ordered.  The beef stew was super rich and flavorful.  The shrimp/sugarcane was good too.  They had large pieces and large portions.  The bean sprouts and basil could have looked fresher, but at that point, I didn't even care.  Also, this has one of the better three colored drinks I've tried.   Overall, it's a great deal.
author: Raz R.

description: I stopped by this place on my way home from work and I'm glad I did. I had the BIGGEST craving for Pho and this place hit the spot! I was surprised by the portions because I thought I was gonna get your traditional large bowl. When my order came, it wasn't just large, it was HUGE!!! If you're not in the mood for Pho, the other times that I have gone there, I got vermicelli noodles with beef and egg rolls. Now, when I go there, i'm stuck on deciding what to get! For the price I paid....i felt like i was ripping them off! Trust me, you're definitely getting your money's worth!!
author: Adam y.

description: Them Ky was one of the very first Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco 's "Little Saigon". I have been regular for years. The food is consistently good and the service is friendly. I really like Them Ky's simple and fresh approach to Pho. (you can order your Pho with either rice vermicelli or the wider rice noodle) I love their Cha Gio and especially the freshly made sandwiches. A great place for tasty food at affordable prices.
author: James W.
